This is a watch party, so grit your teeth and channel your patience; we‚Äôll all hit ‚Äúplay‚Äù together at 9:05 am PDT.

There‚Äôs so much excitement heading toward you this week! There are Q&A opportunities, more watch parties, and don‚Äôt miss Break the SwiftUIce on Wednesday at 6:00pm PDT for a really fun icebreaker. Can‚Äôt get enough SwiftUI? Buzz over to the watchOS channel for great conversations about SwiftUI on Apple Watch, head to the App Services Digital Lounge for WidgetKit activities, and make sure to catch Q&A: Accessibility in SwiftUI in the Accessibility & Inclusion Digital Lounge.

Want even more fun? Might I interest you in Trivia Night? The Developer Tools Digital Lounge is the place to be on Thursday at 6:00pm PDT for a high-energy event.

Don‚Äôt go far; your Digital Lounge activities kick off soon! Can‚Äôt wait to chat with you then!

Hi everyone! Welcome to Meet the Presenters: What‚Äôs New in SwiftUI. We‚Äôre so happy to have you all here! My name is Betsy and I‚Äôm a Framework Evangelist within Worldwide Developer Relations, and it‚Äôs my absolute joy to get to work with the amazing SwiftUI team.

This is a watch party! We‚Äôre joined by presenters Nick and Franck, along with a whole bunch of the SwiftUI team, and we‚Äôre really excited to watch What‚Äôs New in SwiftUI together.

At 9:05am PDT we‚Äôll all hit play on my call, so get that video queued up and your popcorn ready üçø. I know it‚Äôs really exciting but please try to limit yourself to 1x speed. No spoilers allowed from those of you who have read ahead and are living in the future! Where we‚Äôre going, we really do need roads!

To keep everything organized, I‚Äôll be creating threads üßµ as the video progresses that will align with sections of the session. That‚Äôs where everyone can talk and ask questions. When the video finishes, we‚Äôll have time for more in-depth Q&A, but I‚Äôll give you all the details on that when we get there! For now, sit back, relax, and be ready to smash that play button!

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:12:09

*Thread Reply:* That's an interesting question about Pie charts specifically. The data visualization academic community right now has mixed feelings generally about pie charts. They aren't supported in Swift Charts. I'm not data-vis expert though, definitely bring this up in the Charts sessions Curt mentioned

Hello Swift Charts - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Say hello to Swift Charts ‚Äî a flexible framework that helps you create charts entirely in SwiftUI that look and feel right at home on all...

‚ù§Ô∏è Shubham, Petro

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:18:38

*Thread Reply:* > Hi, awesome news about a charting framework: Q - can it be used to show realtime (e.g. sensor) data? @Oliver yes, you can use it with realtime data.

‚ù§Ô∏è Oliver, Christian, Ryan, Yoshihiro
üòÆ Chen-Yu
Chuck
2022-06-07 18:20:17

*Thread Reply:* any support for rendering this to a scalable PDF beyond embedding as an image?

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:23:38

*Thread Reply:* Swift Charts does not support radial layouts so no pie charts or donut charts. However, you can usually show the same data as a bar chart, which may actually be easier to read and is more accessible to e.g. Voice Over users (linear layout is closer to the navigation order in other interface elements).

üëÄ David
Oliver
2022-06-07 18:25:05

*Thread Reply:* @Dominik M (Apple) considering long running sensor data being visualized, what would be a good approach to scroll through it it horizontally? Embed multiple Chart into a scrollview, LazyHGrid? memory pressure and speed is currently killing us in UIKit‚Ä¶ any advise here?

Andrew
2022-06-07 18:25:28

*Thread Reply:* Just checking again ‚Ä¶any hierarchy tree charts available?

Oliver
2022-06-07 18:26:43

*Thread Reply:* (sry for being so specific, and thanks already for this new framework)

üôå Jerome
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:26:47

*Thread Reply:* There is no native support for hierarchical layouts in Swift Charts. you could use it to render the output of a tree layout algorithm (e.g. Treemap) with the rectangle mark but I don‚Äôt think you get that much benefit from Swift Charts over SwiftUI in that case.

üëç Andrew
Andrew
2022-06-07 18:27:40

*Thread Reply:* Thanks

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:28:30

*Thread Reply:* To create a PDF, you can use the ChartRenderer API to render a chart into a CGPDFContext

ü§Ø Nick T (Apple), Oliver, Chuck, Radu, Thorsten, Rafael, Yoshihiro

2022-06-07 18:28:45

*Thread Reply:* @Oliver Good question. The weather app has multiple charts embedded in some scrollview so I suppose that could be a good approach. This could be a good topic for a lab session with the team later this week.

*Thread Reply:* To create a chart-like layout like this, do you recommend using the new Chart library or building it custom with Grids? Are there any performance benefits for one or the other approach?

Screenshot 2022-06-07 at 18.39.23.png
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:43:06

*Thread Reply:* > Hey there, very excited about Charts! Do we get the Audio Charts for free when using native charts or do we still have to provide a chart descriptor? Yes, you get Audio Graph support automatically. However, the framework can only infer so much automatically so you may still want to override the default to get the best experience for your VoiceOver users.

üôå Tomas
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:44:02

*Thread Reply:* > Are doughnut and pie charts also supported? @David No. But you can use a bar chart instead. See my the discussion above.

üëç David, Regina
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:44:51

*Thread Reply:* > To create a chart-like layout like this, do you recommend using the new Chart library or building it custom with Grids? Are there any performance benefits for one or the other approach? You can use Swift Charts. You will get the axes and color scale for free and also better performance (I think but would need to try).

üëç Christian
Oliver
2022-06-07 18:45:09

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:46:28

*Thread Reply:* We can‚Äôt talk about plans for the future.

There is a chart reader that you can use for interactions. Check out the ‚ÄúRaise the Bar‚Äù talk.

Betsy L (Apple)

2022-06-07 18:12:08

*Thread Reply:* Soft-deprecated. We recommend against it in new code, but it would not be a compile time warning.

Thomas
2022-06-07 18:31:37

*Thread Reply:* Is there a way to detect that a NavigationLink was activated by the user without having access to the stack path? It was formerly possible by observing the Binding&lt;Bool&gt;, but I'm not seeing how to do this right now.

Thomas
2022-06-07 18:31:51

*Thread Reply:* I've filled FB10069073 about this issue

‚ù§Ô∏è Paris P (Apple), Curt C (Apple)
Thomas
2022-06-07 18:33:28

*Thread Reply:* Also, is a NavigationLink with value equivalent to a button that appends the value to the current stack path?

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:33:30

*Thread Reply:* @Thomas check out the SwiftUI Navigation Cookbook talk, there is a lot of flexibility that you can get from having full control cover the path

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:34:07

*Thread Reply:* The path of a NavigationStack doesn't necessarily have to live in the same View as the stack ‚Äî it can be higher up in your app's architecture

üíØ Paris P (Apple), Ruchish, Yi-ying
Thomas
2022-06-07 18:38:04

*Thread Reply:* My concern was to work in a leaf view without any path knowledge, while still being able to locally perform logic when some NavigationLink is activated. The objective is to avoid leaking the parent model into the child, but still have some logic around navigation being performed by the child.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:38:14

*Thread Reply:* > Is there a way to detect that a NavigationLink was activated by the user without having access to the stack path? It was formerly possible by observing the Binding&lt;Bool&gt;, but I‚Äôm not seeing how to do this right now. One approach is to bind a path to the surrounding NavigationStack. Then use an onChange modifier to observe the path.

üëç Yi-ying
Thomas
2022-06-07 18:39:58

*Thread Reply:* @Curt C (Apple) The idea was to perform the check locally, without any access to the stack or its path.

Kai
2022-06-07 18:40:54

*Thread Reply:* Are there any plans for backward compatibility for the new navigation APIs e.g. for iOS 15?

üôå Lawrence
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:42:52

*Thread Reply:* > @Curt C (Apple) The idea was to perform the check locally, without any access to the stack or its path. Thanks for the FB! Could you add some more details to it about the sort of work you‚Äôre looking to do when the link is activated?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:44:08

*Thread Reply:* Alternatively, you could have a button that appends to the path. To get the data separation you‚Äôre looking for, you might need to pass an action in the environment or as a parameter that would do the appending.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:44:47

*Thread Reply:* > Are there any plans for backward compatibility for the new navigation APIs e.g. for iOS 15? Kai, I‚Äôm afraid it isn‚Äôt technically possible to back port these APIs.

Thomas
2022-06-07 18:44:59

*Thread Reply:* @Curt C (Apple) Yes, I'll improve the feedback, but the end-goal would be to drive the navigation programmatically with TCA. We need to setup some piece of state and then append the corresponding value to the path.

Thomas
2022-06-07 18:45:32

*Thread Reply:* But if a Button is equivalent in terms of rendering/behavior, that's indeed a possible workaround.

Bardia
2022-06-07 18:45:43

*Thread Reply:* <deleted / asked in the right place>

Thomas
2022-06-07 18:46:07

*Thread Reply:* My concern with NavigationLink with value is that the values are eagerly evaluated.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:47:09

*Thread Reply:* Only for links that are on-screen or in an eager container.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:50:15

*Thread Reply:* > Hi All. I‚Äôm just wondering whether matchedGeometryEffect can work when navigating between views using the NavigationStack? So, for example, imagine tapping on a card on a ScrollView to open a fullscreen view of the card (i.e. like the App Store) using NavigationStack/matchedGeometryEffect? NavigationStack uses the system-standard push-pop animations. You might try creating a custom overlay for this use case, so the card would not be part of the path.

Thomas
2022-06-07 18:50:20

*Thread Reply:* Ideally, the value would only be created when the link is activated.

Thomas
2022-06-07 18:50:55

*Thread Reply:* But maybe there are some internal constraints forcing an eager evaluation.

Bardia
2022-06-07 18:53:02

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Curt C (Apple) for the clarification.

Thomas
2022-06-07 18:55:01

*Thread Reply:* If Button is equivalent to NavigationLink in terms of UI or behavior, then I have no concern with eager evaluation.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:55:15

*Thread Reply:* > Ideally, the value would only be created when the link is activated. Could I trouble you for a brief Feedback on this? An autoclosure might be reasonable here.

üëç Thomas
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:56:02

*Thread Reply:* NavigationLink gets the chevron in some contexts, but is otherwise a button.

*Thread Reply:* Would it be possible to have / pass separate NSManagedObjectContext for each window? Reason: Like for example if I have multiple windows on a Mac app and I want to create something temporary on to a specific window till the user decides to save it and make it available on all windows

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:33:14

*Thread Reply:* Hmm, thats an interesting question. You could take a look at the new WindowGroup initializer which takes a binding to a value presented for the window. You could potentially use this value to determine your managed object context. More info on this will also be in the 'Bring Multiple Windows to your SwiftUI app' session on Friday

üôå Muthuveerappan

‚ù§Ô∏è Betsy L (Apple), Sam L (Apple), Kevin
üëÄ Kenneth
Matthew K (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:27:45

*Thread Reply:* Accessibility Quick Actions on watchOS is super cool. Instead of having AssistiveTouch on all the time, you can have it on just to do quick things in your app with a gesture.

For example, you can enable QuickActions to answer a phone call with just one hand -- clench your fist, and it performs the action.

Using .accessibilityQuickAction is an easy way to add that functionality to your app.

ü§Ø Jakub, Josh, Monica, Rachel
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:28:20

*Thread Reply:* Avoid using tap gestures for button-like things. Custom button styles will provide a better user experience, both in interaction handling and accessibility.

‚úÖ Kevin, Sam L (Apple)

*Thread Reply:* > I remember before from the NavigationView API, that when SwiftUI automatically switches from a split navigation style to the stack navigation style, for example when switching from portrait to landscape on iPhone 12 Pro Max, the selection state wasn‚Äôt preserved and some UI glitches happen. Was that all solved with the new APIs? It should be easier with the new API, but it‚Äôs also possible that the selection issues were caused by how the app modeled the data.

I guess I‚Äôm saying it‚Äôs still possible to ~right~ write bugs. üôÇ

2022-06-07 18:31:50

*Thread Reply:* Also Transferable code snippet didn‚Äôt work. ```struct ContentView: View {

let photo = Photo(image: Image(systemName: "pencil"), caption: "Pencil")

struct Photo: Transferable {

    static var transferRepresentation: some TransferRepresentation {
        ProxyRepresentation(exporting: \.image)
    }
    var image: Image
    var caption: String
}

var body: some View {
    photo.image
        .toolbar {
            ShareLink(
                item: photo,
                preview: SharePreview(photo.caption,image: photo.image)
            )
        }
}

}```

*Thread Reply:* Something we couldn't talk about in the talk (for brevity) was how complex these new shadows are. Not only do they composite on top of each other as you'd expect, but if you apply a shadow on a translucent shape, the shadow will not show through the translucency

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:45:03

@Ethan asked > With graphics and custom layouts being added, when should we use native elements vs custom styling? How far should custom designs go?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:45:12

*Thread Reply:* It entirely depends on your use case! We ultimately trust your sense of design on this one since only you know what‚Äôs right for your app. To give some general guidance though: Take native elements as far as you can, and if you find you need further customization beyond that to finely polish the experience, then don‚Äôt be afraid to use it!

One quick disclaimer: It can be easy to drop to custom layouts prematurely. Stacks and Grids are incredibly powerful already, so be sure you can‚Äôt get what you need with them before you use the new layout protocol. (edited)

üôå Ethan, Rafael
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:46:11

@Josh asked > I saw that VStack and HStack conform to Layout. Does that mean using an if-else to switch between the two with the same content will now animate the change?

Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:47:24

*Thread Reply:* Yes!

üëÄ Kenneth
üôå John G (Apple), Abdulaziz, Josh, Nrick
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:47:31

*Thread Reply:* To animate between layouts you'll need to switch between the layouts using AnyLayout for example:

let layout = isVertical ? AnyLayout(VStack()) : AnyLayout(HStack()) layout { Text("Hi") Text("World") }

‚ù§Ô∏è Paris P (Apple), Michael, John G (Apple), Tom, Thomas, Robert, August J (Apple), Yi-ying, Ruchish, Ron, Kai, Michel, An, Radu, Rudrank, Nrick, Mike, John, YONGXING, Manoj, Zhiyu, Divya, Lahrasub, Melvin
ü§© Chen-Yu, Rudrank, Divya

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:48:08

@Lukas asked > Hi great stuff so far. Thank you! I was wondering if there are any updates, or opinionated best practices when it comes to large scaled applications using SwiftUI in terms of state management and dependency management/injection. Thanks ‚úåÔ∏è

üëç Benjamin, Ruchish, Eduardo, Romy, Radu, Austin
Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:48:17

*Thread Reply:* SwiftUI is not opinionated on a specific architecture for state management. We offer the building blocks to build whatever best fit your use case.

It might be good to sign up for a lab so that we can discuss the specific of your use case and give you targeted advices

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:51:35

@Andrew asked > Does Grid replace VGrid?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:54:18

*Thread Reply:* LazyVGrid and LazyHGrid arrange their children lazily and so are great fits for large amounts of content within a scroll view

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:55:04

*Thread Reply:* Grid requires all of its children be loaded up front and because of that has some powerful features that the lazy grids do not

üëç Yi-Shan, Eduardo, Krishna, Nrick, John, Rudrank, Sergio Andres, Melvin
Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:55:29

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, check out the Composing custom layouts with SwiftUI talk tomorrow for more info

üëç Andrew, Andrew
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:52:05

@Miguel asked > Is there any new control in SwiftUI like the NSSegmentedControl used under tables to add / delete a row? This is a common pattern in macOS applications and the current SwiftUI segmented control does not fit to this use case.

Taylor K (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:53:35

*Thread Reply:* Good news: There‚Äôs not a new control, but an old one üòÑ

Last year we introduced ControlGroup that enables building these kinds of controls (which you might have used NSSegmentedControl for with AppKit). You can create one with Buttons, Toggles, and more!

Miguel
2022-06-07 18:58:28

*Thread Reply:* Nice, didn‚Äôt know about this one. Will try it out. Thanks! üëç

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:53:13

@Yugantar asked > What is the difference between .onChange and .onReceive modifier.? ".onReceive is like a combination of .onAppear and .onChange", is this the complete and accurate picture?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:53:20

*Thread Reply:* onReceive is specifically to subscribe to Combine‚Äôs Publisher types and produce a side effect.

onChange is used to produce a side effect when a property of your view changes. For example you can use that to produce a side effect when the scene phase in the environment changes.

üëç Yugantar
Yugantar
2022-06-07 18:58:22

*Thread Reply:* Okay, thank you for the explanation! If I use both .onReceive and .onChange on a Published property, will there be a difference in behaviour and is one recommended over the other in this case?

Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:00:17

*Thread Reply:* It really depends on your use case: Is the value equatable? Is it a lightweight event? Does your view have constraints to adhere to, such as de-duping, debouncing, exponential backoff, etc.

üëç Yugantar
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:54:22

@Austin asked > Curious if there's updates related to UI testing in SwiftUI apps? Or should I be thinking more in terms of testing the model layer that drives the declarative UI?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:54:27

*Thread Reply:* Our recommendation is still to thoroughly test your model layer. In my experience, the best SwiftUI apps move their logic into model code, using SwiftUI as a declarative mapping from that model state to views. Then your tests of the model layer are effectively tests of the resulting UI as well üôÇ

üëç Austin, Yi-ying, Jeannine, Jordan, Oscar, Lee, Abdulaziz, Igor, Bryan, Rhys, Brandon, Alisan, Melvin
‚ù§Ô∏è Jeannine
üíØ Paris P (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:56:36

@Josh asked > Is it possible enumerate a NavigationPath or replace certain elements?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:58:17

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs not currently possible to enumerate a NavigationPath. Because it‚Äôs type-erased, the elements could only be exposed as any Hashable so aren‚Äôt directly useful.

üëÄ Mateusz, Rudrank
üëç Yi-Shan
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:59:22

*Thread Reply:* Generally, if the set of things that can be added to a path form a closed set, which would be the case if you can usefully enumerate it, I‚Äôd recommend wrapping your presented values in an enum with associated types.

Josh
2022-06-07 18:59:26

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôm wondering if having a mutable collection of enum values might be generally more useful than using a NavigationPath.

Josh
2022-06-07 18:59:35

*Thread Reply:* Snap!

üòÉ Curt C (Apple)
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:59:47

*Thread Reply:* Then use an array of that enum instead of NavigationPath.

Josh
2022-06-07 18:59:55

*Thread Reply:* Sounds like that could work better and might fit nicely with some form of Coordinator-esque style pattern.

üëç Curt C (Apple), Matt
Josh
2022-06-07 19:00:09

*Thread Reply:* Thanks!

2022-06-07 18:59:05

@Robert asked > Terrific updates all around! When animating the Font on a Text, when can we expect the font to smoothly interpolate instead of crossfade?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:00:54

*Thread Reply:* Generally changing weights and sizes of the same font will interpolate, but not changing fonts

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:00:57

@MINSHENG asked > Does the new NavigationSplitView preserve state when we switch to a new navigation destination like tab bar in UIKit, or do we need to roll our state restoration, like what we had to deal with using the old TabView?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:02:35

*Thread Reply:* If you want to switch to a TabView in narrow size classes, you‚Äôll want to design a navigation model type that provides selection information for the NavigationSplitView in regular size classes and a different projection of the same information to a TabView that‚Äôs shown in narrow size classes.

üëç Krishna
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:03:13

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôd love Feedback with specific use cases. I‚Äôm very interested in making this easier.

üôå Rudrank, Yugantar

2022-06-07 19:01:13

@Miguel asked > Does Transferable also support asynchronous behavior like NSFilePromiseProvider, e.g. if you do not have an file URL yet (e.g. cause a file first needs to be downloaded from a web server, but only when the drag operation ends)

Taylor K (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:05:42

*Thread Reply:* Definitely, the FileRepresentation transfer representation does what you‚Äôre describing. @Julia V (Apple)‚Äôs amazing talk ‚ÄúMeet Transferable‚Äù will be out with more detail tomorrow ( June 8 ) üòÑ

:swift_blue: Sam L (Apple), Evelyn R (Apple), Julia V (Apple), Melvin
üôå Miguel
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:01:27

@Thomas asked > What is the correct way to implement invalidation when conforming some type to DynamicProperty? Should hosting another builtin DynamicProperty enough? Are these wrapped properties like @State or @ObservedObject guaranteed to work as expected in DynamicProperty?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:02:52

*Thread Reply:* Dynamic properties are fully composable, so any other dynamic properties you use inside of their declarations will be picked up on and invalidated properly. That means supporting invalidation as you would expect is often just a matter of utilizing the support already built into other dynamic properties, like @State

üëç Thomas, Jordan, Philip
Evelyn R (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:55:36

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:05:29

@Hugo asked > Hi, is there anything different visually, to the user, between a NavigationView and a NavigationStack?

‚ûï Andrew, John, Mayra M
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:06:08

*Thread Reply:* They‚Äôre both structural components, but they do behave a bit differently.

Hugo
2022-06-08 00:06:37

*Thread Reply:* Can you elaborate in what way they behave differently?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:07:07

*Thread Reply:* NavigationView renders differently depending on how many views you pass to it and what navigationViewStyle you set on it.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:07:28

*Thread Reply:* NavigationStack takes a single root view and always renders as a stack.

Hugo
2022-06-08 00:09:27

*Thread Reply:* Gotcha, thanks for the clarification :)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:08:23

@John asked > Is it possible to reorder items and insert into an outline group?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:09:38

*Thread Reply:* SwiftUI doesn‚Äôt have much in the way of automatic support for that, I‚Äôm afraid. I‚Äôd love a Feedback with details of your specific use case.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:11:30

*Thread Reply:* We did expose public API for disclosureGroupStyle this year, which might be worth investigating.

John
2022-06-08 00:16:49

*Thread Reply:* The use case would be a sidebar that the user can organize on their own.

I was thinking this could be a normal list, but there a limits with cross-section item moves that I end up tripping over.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:19:14

*Thread Reply:* Makes sense. With the current API, I‚Äôd use a view model that vends the items as if they are a flat array, then style the items based on their apparent depth. That would let you use onMove or the awesome new editing support on List to update your view model.

John
2022-06-08 00:22:41

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, I think biggest trick there is figuring out that ‚Äúoffset 20‚Äù is actually ‚Äúoffset 2 of parent 4‚Äù or something like that.

Thanks for your input. It's not the first time I've read this solution, and since there's nothing new in this area for 2022, I think I may need to take the plunge and go for it.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:10:00

@Jeannine asked > Pages and Numbers are both document-based apps which have a beautiful onboarding experience. How do I build such an onboarding experience for my document-based app using SwiftUI?

‚ûï Susannah, Adam
Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:12:05

*Thread Reply:* Hi - this is a great question! While we do not currently have a high-level concept in SwiftUI for this type of flow, it may be possible to combine the new Window scene together with the new OpenDocumentAction and NewDocumentAction to create it. You would need to define the Window as the primary (first) scene in your app, however. It's possible there may be some drawbacks to this approach, so I'd love a feedback for an enhancement in this area.

üëç Adam
Jeannine
2022-06-08 00:13:23

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the idea. I'll try!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:10:39

@Andrew asked > I currently use NavigationView in my app with NavigationLink to go from parent view to child destination view. It works fine for what I want. Do I need to migrate to using NavigationStack in my case, especially if I‚Äôm just linking to destination views and not needing to link by value?

üôå Romy
Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:11:16

*Thread Reply:* NavigationView is only soft-deprecated and so will continue to work fine in all its existing use cases with no compiler warnings. If writing new code, however, we recommend you start using NavigationStack.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:12:39

@Kevin asked > On iPadOS in a NavigationView, Is it possible to switch between two column and three column layout depending on what is selected in my sidebar?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:13:23

*Thread Reply:* It isn‚Äôt possible to do that directly.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:14:16

*Thread Reply:* Often those style of UIs can be built by swapping the view in the detail area between a single root view and an HStack with two-elements.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:15:07

*Thread Reply:* That is, instead of conceiving of it as a two or three column NavigationSplitView, think of it as a two-column one, where the detail column itself has one or two columns.

Kevin
2022-06-08 00:15:30

*Thread Reply:* Great, that's exactly what I'm doing now. It's working fine, just a little extra work to coordinate with my compact view. Thanks!

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:15:53

*Thread Reply:* Awesome! I‚Äôm glad you found a solution.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:13:20

@Jordan asked > Is there a better way to prevent DynamicProperty from invalidating a view‚Äôs body based on different criteria? I am currently doing this with a private ObservableObject backing that manages its objectWillSend calls, which seems to works well but also feels like I am doing some backflips (the context is being able to scope in on specific changes on an ObservableObject model for performance reasons).

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:16:14

*Thread Reply:* There is no direct way to prevent DynamicProperty from updating.

What you are doing is a way to do it. If the purpose is to manage ObservableObject invalidation I would suggest consider refactoring your model into multiple model. Keep in mind that you can also implement your own objectWillChange Publisher.

Jordan
2022-06-08 00:17:41

*Thread Reply:* Makes sense. Thanks!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:16:17

@Brett asked > Previously in NavigationView on iPad, the detail view would be displayed with the ForEach list being collapsed in a sidebar. With the new NavigationSplitView, can I use a modifier to not collapse the ForEach list?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:17:03

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the question. NavigationSplitView takes a columnVisibility binding. You can set it to .all to reveal all the columns programmatically!

Brett
2022-06-08 00:18:21

*Thread Reply:* Great, thank you!

2022-06-08 00:20:35

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:20:58

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a method that I implemented on my NavigationModel but didn‚Äôt fit into the slides.

Malcolm
2022-06-08 00:21:27

*Thread Reply:* Ok thanks

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:21:29

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs in the Copy Code for the talk accessible in the Developer app though

Christian
2022-06-08 00:21:31

*Thread Reply:* I think you can use for await _ in store.objectWillChange.values in a similar way?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:21:43

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs close, Christian!

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:21:52

*Thread Reply:* You have to buffer the values too.

üëç Christian
üíØ Paris P (Apple)
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:22:22

*Thread Reply:* var objectWillChangeSequence: AsyncPublisher&lt;Publishers.Buffer&lt;ObservableObjectPublisher&gt;&gt; { objectWillChange .buffer(size: 1, prefetch: .byRequest, whenFull: .dropOldest) .values }

‚úÖ Christian, Lee, Oliver, Christopher
Malcolm
2022-06-08 00:22:59

2022-06-08 00:23:35

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:23:48

üëÄ Malcolm
üôå Malcolm
‚ù§Ô∏è Paris P (Apple)
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:24:14

*Thread Reply:* The sample app is a little more complex than what I shared in the talk.

Muthuveerappan
2022-06-08 00:36:35

Curt C (Apple)

*Thread Reply:* I used task in the talk so the restore and save code was in one block, but splitting them into separate onAppear and onChange should also work.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:21:27

@Ryan asked > How does ViewThatFits decide if a view fits? I find it a bit strange that Text with a line limit of 1 still "fits" even if it's truncated for example.

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:21:57

*Thread Reply:* ViewThatFits consults the view's ideal frame size for both dimensions.

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:23:21

*Thread Reply:* The latter behavior isn't intended. A feedback # and keeping an eye on later seeds is a good strategy here

Ryan
2022-06-08 00:27:48

*Thread Reply:* Adding a fixedSize(horizontal: true, vertical: false) seems to fix the issue but also seems unnecessary. I‚Äôll file a feedback

Ryan
2022-06-08 00:32:03

*Thread Reply:* FB10082577

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:33:56

*Thread Reply:* 2 for Ryan üôÇ

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:21:41

@Ashish asked > Does Swift Charts have a way to highlight values on a line chart for a specific X position?

üëÄ Ryan, John
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:23:55

*Thread Reply:* There's a Swift Charts Q&A at 11am PT on Thu. Please ask there!

üëç Kim
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:24:41

*Thread Reply:* In the meantime, you can always try drawing an additional mark for the highlight.

Sara F (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:26:24

*Thread Reply:* Its possible to modify the .foregroundStyle to have a different color per X position, it depends on what kind of highlight you want to call out. It might be possible to do an annotation as well but the charts team will be the experts!

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:28:49

*Thread Reply:* The Build a Productivity App for Apple Watch talk, coming tomorrow, has an example of exactly that!

‚ù§Ô∏è Sara F (Apple), Richard W (Apple)
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:28:50

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10133

Apple Developer
Build a productivity app for Apple Watch - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Your wrist has never been more productive. Discover how you can use SwiftUI and system features to build a great productivity app for...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10133
Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:45:24

*Thread Reply:* You can use PointMark (possibly with annotations) to highlight values on a line, such as: Chart { // Create the line. ForEach(data) { LineMark( x: .value("X", $0.x), y: .value("Y", $0.y) ) } // Highlight a point. PointMark( x: .value("Highlight X", 10), y: .value("Highlight Y", 50) ) .foregroundStyle(highlightColor) // You can also add textual annotations to the point: .annotation(position: .top) { Text("Highlight") } }

‚ûï Richard W (Apple)
‚ù§Ô∏è Lahrasub
Ashish
2022-06-08 01:58:53

*Thread Reply:* I am sorry for not being clear. What I want is having a vertical line when I tap on a specific X position so that all datapoints on that X position are highlighted.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-08 03:14:32

*Thread Reply:* You would decompose the problem into 1) using a chart proxy to get the x position for a tap and 2) highlighting the data points at that x. The lollipop tooltip we have in the Swift Charts sample app may be a starting point to look at.

üëç Ashish
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:22:07

@Harry asked > Is there a way to access DragSession from DropDelegate (like UIKit)?

Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:29:45

*Thread Reply:* Hi Harry, this API is not available. However, we'd be interested in learning more about your use case here. Could you please explain your scenario and the expected behavior in Feedback Assistant for the SwiftUI team to consider for a future release?

üëå Harry
Harry
2022-06-08 00:31:52

*Thread Reply:* Will do One primary use is to determine if the drag started from the same app (either same view or from another scene) The other reason is to use that to pass data (where NSItemProvider works but is async and may be out of order)

Bardia
2022-06-08 00:35:20

*Thread Reply:* This could be semi-related, but at the moment if a drag begins and ends without any movement (i.e. you let your finger go immediately after the drag was activated) there‚Äôs no communication back to the app. So, for example, if the drag trigger activates a specific UI state, then when the drag is released, it won‚Äôt be de-activated because it considers the drag to still be (incorrectly) active.

‚òùÔ∏è Christopher
Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:41:04

*Thread Reply:* Yes, I think both of these use cases should be captured as feedback. Providing context like this is very helpful in prioritizing new features. Thank you, both

üëç Bardia, Harry
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:27:32

@Angela asked > how can i get simething similar to autolayout priorities, of being able to have 2 views in a stack equal but only up to a certain width

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:29:48

*Thread Reply:* You can pass any kind of information you like to an adopter of Layout. So that "certain width" could be passed to the instance of the Layout itself. And the layout priority can be provided via the subviews proxy of Layout.

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:30:44

*Thread Reply:* In the swiftinterface file there is discussion of this:

/// Views have layout values that you set with view modifiers. /// Layout containers can choose to condition their behavior accordingly. /// For example, a built-in ``HStack`` allocates space to its subviews based /// in part on the priorities that you set with the ``View/layoutPriority(_:)`` /// view modifier. Your layout container accesses this value for a subview by /// reading the proxy's ``LayoutSubview/priority`` property.

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:32:36

*Thread Reply:* You can see the rendered version of that text in the docs under the heading ‚ÄúAccess Layout Values‚Äù: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/layout

üôè Nick T (Apple)
Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:40:04

*Thread Reply:* Thinking about this more....

Reasoning about this in terms of autolayout might make things tricker than they need to be, especially for 2 views. For instance you could instead use a custom LayoutValueKey to say that View A should take 70% of the proposed size, and View B should take 30%.

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:41:30

*Thread Reply:* Rough sample code: MyCustomLayout(widthThreshold: 300.0) { viewA.oversizedWidthPercentage(0.7) viewB.oversizedWidthPercentage(0.3) }

Angela
2022-06-08 00:45:41

*Thread Reply:* i was thinking something more like breaking "constraints" due to certain conditions based (if possible)

Alexander
2022-06-09 22:07:40

*Thread Reply:* Is there something similar for simple Views? E.g. a view which calculates its required height based on the available width. What's the best practice to solve something like this?

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:29:15

@Radu asked > What's the intended use for DynamicProperty's update() method? It seems most of the time the DynamicProperty's members are @Stateful objects managing their own state and using update() with them requires a dispatch async (to the next runloop cycle).

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:31:36

*Thread Reply:* You‚Äôre definitely correct that the state management dynamic properties do is usually handled using their own sub-dynamic properties, and custom logic! The update method is called directly before the corresponding view‚Äôs body is called, and is more a place for any logic that needs to happen before body runs to occur.

Radu
2022-06-08 00:35:45

*Thread Reply:* So, for things that I assume are not stateful in nature, just derivates of the state?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:45:10

*Thread Reply:* That tends to be the case. That said, there may be some examples of property wrappers that use information about when the view is rendered to drive stateful systems. When debugging, I‚Äôll sometimes use a DynamicProperty with an Int wrappedValue that increments whenever the surrounding view‚Äôs body is drawn, for example üôÇ

Radu
2022-06-08 00:48:26

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a neat trick! Thanks for sharing and for the answer!

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:53:04

*Thread Reply:* Of course! Thanks for the question!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:29:18

@Malcolm asked > Can we set the NavigationPath from onContinueUserActivity and onOpenURL?

üëÄ Cristina
Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:30:46

*Thread Reply:* Hi - great question! This is certainly something you can do, and is a good example of how you can support something like deep linking, for example, by parsing the URL provided to onOpenURL and using it to construct your navigation path.

üëç Malcolm, Mihai, Eugene
üëç:skin_tone_2: Cristina
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:30:46

@Kenneth asked > Is there a way to show a preview of a view when the user taps and holds on a NavigationLink (similar to how a website is previewed when holding on a link in Safari)? I tried using the contextMenu modifier, but it only seems to render Button views. > > NavigationLink( ... ) > .contextMenu { > ViewIWantToPreview() // is not previewed > Button { ... } // other options show correctly > }

Raj R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:31:28

*Thread Reply:* Yes, use the new contextMenu overload that accepts a preview view.

NavigationLink( ... ) .contextMenu { Button { ... } } preview: { ViewIWantToPreview() }

üëç Mihai, Kenneth, John, Muthuveerappan, Brandon, Melvin
üî• Steven, Evelyn R (Apple), Muthuveerappan, Christian, Magnus, Jaanus, Melvin
John
2022-06-08 00:35:32

*Thread Reply:* Wow, handy. Nice work!

Kenneth
2022-06-08 00:36:22

*Thread Reply:* Thank you, this seems to work quite well! This was one of the things I was stuck trying to figure out for a while while making my Swift Student Challenge submission (and ultimately never figured out üòÖ)

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:38:07

*Thread Reply:* Here‚Äôs some more detail on that new modifier: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/view/contextmenu(menuitems:preview:)

üôå Kenneth, Jaanus
Kenneth
2022-06-08 00:40:33

*Thread Reply:* Can I have the user tap the preview to open another view (the ‚Äúfull‚Äù view) as well? I'm playing around with it in Xcode previews and it seems like tapping the preview just closes the context menu.

Raj R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:43:33

*Thread Reply:* No, it's not currently supported‚Äî please file a feedback request.

2022-06-08 00:56:00

*Thread Reply:* Alright, done! FB10083104 Thanks for the SwiftUI improvements this year by the way, they've been great!

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:39:02

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:40:29

@Josiah asked > Hello all, i believe this is the channel for this question. I‚Äôm wanting to get your take on how SwiftUI‚Äôs data flow can change how we architect our apps? It seems as if, with EnvironmentObjects, ObservableObjects and possibly more, they change where you get your data from, which could cause variations in, let‚Äôs say MVVM. What do you guys think is a good way to make use of these property wrappers and could it change how we architect things? Thanks!

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:40:37

*Thread Reply:* The data flow primitives we provide in SwiftUI were designed to be agnostic to the way you design your model. Think of them less as parts of a specific design pattern and more as tools to allow you to hook your model (however you think it would be best designed) into SwiftUI.

If you want more information on this, I recommend you check out the fantastic talk by my colleagues, Raj, and Luca: Data Essentials in SwiftUI

Apple Developer
Data Essentials in SwiftUI - WWDC20 - Videos - Apple Developer
Data is a complex part of any app, but SwiftUI makes it easy to ensure a smooth, data-driven experience from prototyping to production...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10040/
Josiah
2022-06-08 00:44:56

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the response, that‚Äôs an excellent way of putting it. It‚Äôs definitely difficult explaining this to an Android developer who relies on older ‚Äúarchitecture‚Äù or design patterns. This will probably help a lot. I‚Äôm not sure if this would be good to add here, but i created some SwiftUI pattern i think could be beneficial for my team and it leverages wrappers. The thing is, it‚Äôs difficult convincing others that it could work since this is how SwiftUI handles data flow. I will definitely check out this video though, this is what i was envisioning too, maybe you can provide some feedback if any:

Screen Shot 2022-06-07 at 5.56.02 PM.png
Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:51:42

*Thread Reply:* Providing feedback on specific designs is hard to do in this venue, but definitely sign up for a lab! They tend to do better for long-form discussions / questions.

Josiah
2022-06-08 00:55:12

*Thread Reply:* Great! I will sign up for the SwiftUI Lab thanks.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:40:55

@Christian asked > What is the best way to resign (text field) focus from some distant view in the view hierarchy. scrollDismissesKeyboard is a great step in the direction I need, but I'd like to programmatically trigger that same behavior, for example, on some button tap.

Christian
2022-06-08 00:41:29

*Thread Reply:* For example, looking at ways to replace this code:

```UIApplication.shared .sendAction(#selector(UIResponder.resignFirstResponder), to: nil, from: nil, for: nil)

// as an action to perform on a view:

extension View { func resignFocus() { UIApplication.shared.sendAction(...) } }```

Cody B (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:42:10

*Thread Reply:* You can do this with the Focus State API: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/focusstate

You want to bind a focus state property to your text field using View.focused(_:equals:), and then set the binding's value to nil/false from your button action as a way to programmatically resign focus and dismiss the keyboard when the bound text field has focus.

Making the action available to distant views is a matter of arranging your app's data flow appropriately. There's no single answer, but for example, you could declare your focus state property on your scene's root view and pass a reset action down to any descendant views that need it. Or if the action is created by a leaf view, you can use the preferences system to make the action available to ancestors.

üëç Christian
üëç:skin_tone_4: Joshua
Christian
2022-06-08 00:43:41

*Thread Reply:* Preferences is an interesting idea. Trying to make the focusstate ‚Äúglobally accessible‚Äù was challenging. I‚Äôll give these suggestions a shot! Thanks.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:43:15

@Radu asked > Not sure if this was already asked before since it's such a common question. But, what's the recommended way to use a @ViewBuilder for custom components: calling it right away in the init() and storing the view, or calling it later inside the body and storing the view builder itself?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:43:33

*Thread Reply:* We‚Äôd generally recommend resolving it right away and storing the view

üëç Radu, Mihai
üíØ Paris P (Apple)
Radu
2022-06-08 00:44:17

*Thread Reply:* Thank you, much appreciated!

Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:44:43

*Thread Reply:* Storing the view will have better performance than storing a closure (potentially avoiding allocations).

Of course, if you need to dynamically resolve a view from a closure (such as if it takes parameters), then storing the closure is also fine!

‚ûï Sam L (Apple)
üëç Radu, Klayton
Ryan
2022-06-08 00:45:27

*Thread Reply:* Is this the same for Layout? The example code for AnyLayout shows creating a layout in the body instead of in the View.

Christian
2022-06-08 00:46:51

*Thread Reply:* You can now (last year?) also declare the viewbuilder as just a property. In SwiftUI 1, you had to manually implement the init, but no longer needed. Best (IMHO) to use synthesized init when you can.

```struct MyView<Content: View>: View {

@ViewBuilder var content: Content

}``` (I believe is the correct code, coding from memory)

üëç Matt R (Apple), Sam L (Apple), Radu
üëç:skin_tone_5: Paris P (Apple)
Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:48:00

*Thread Reply:* Yes you can attach @ViewBuilder to properties!

You can actually support it on both view and closure properties, depending on whichever you need:

```struct MyView<Content: View>: View {

@ViewBuilder var content: Content

// or

@ViewBuilder var content: (Int) -> Content

}```

üëÄ Christian, Radu
Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:49:36

*Thread Reply:* > Is this the same for Layout? The example code for AnyLayout shows creating a layout in the body instead of in the View. Apologies, not sure I fully understand the question. Just in case: creating views in body is fine, we‚Äôre specifically talking about stored properties, and storing views versus closures for creating views.

‚úÖ Ryan
Muthuveerappan
2022-06-08 00:55:07

*Thread Reply:* Sorry not sure if this is not the right place to ask this. When a view uses ScrollViewReader and the parent view‚Äôs state changes, the the child view gets reloaded and the scroll position in the child view changes. This happens only when scroll(to:) has been executed. I have filed a feedback FB10037533

Cristina
2022-06-08 01:09:59

*Thread Reply:* Talking about this, can you confirm it‚Äôs best for performance to have the @ViewBuilder be a computed (lazy ?) var than a function in my View struct whenever possible?

Chang
2022-06-08 18:10:14

*Thread Reply:* BTW there is a 3rd-party article explains why the view is preferable than the closure https://rensbr.eu/blog/swiftui-escaping-closures/ (If you don‚Äôt mind posting 3rd-party article)

üíØ Aviel
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:52:12

@Ryan asked > When using the Layout protocol, is it possible to resolve an alignment guide for the layout container, not a subview, to align the subviews relative to the container correctly? For instance, a Layout that proposes size (100, 50) would resolve HorizontalAlignment.center to 50 (if unmodified). If not, what is the correct way to do this?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:53:19

*Thread Reply:* You may be able to use the alignmentGuide modifier to define how an alignment guide for a view will resolve

Ryan
2022-06-08 00:54:53

*Thread Reply:* My goal is to get the CGFloat value from the container view for its own alignment guides in the placeSubviews function. (Specifically, to do a layout similar to VStack where the children align in the left middle or right)

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:56:49

*Thread Reply:* Well, you get the bounds of the region that you are laying out inside of, so you can know the midpoint in each dimension, for example

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:58:14

*Thread Reply:* You can also set explicit alignment guides for the layout container by implementing either or both of the explicit alignment methods: ‚Ä¢ https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/layout/explicitalignment(of:in:proposal:subviews:cache:)-8ofeu ‚Ä¢ https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/layout/explicitalignment(of:in:proposal:subviews:cache:)-3iqmu

Ryan
2022-06-08 00:58:50

*Thread Reply:* Ok, thank you. I also thought maybe using the largest subviews‚Äô guides as the base, then it would work with custom AlignmentIDs

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:54:55

@Ryan asked > What happens to a subview if you don't call .place() on it in placeSubviews in a Layout? What happens if you call it twice?

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:55:14

*Thread Reply:* If you call the method more than once for a subview, the last call takes precedence. If you don‚Äôt call this method for a subview, the subview appears at the center of its layout container and uses the layout container‚Äôs size proposal.

üëç Ryan, Adrien
Ryan
2022-06-08 00:57:39

*Thread Reply:* I found this function a bit strange as I was expecting it to return an array of placements instead of running a place function. Is it more efficient the way it‚Äôs set currently set up?

Ryan
2022-06-08 01:01:29

*Thread Reply:* Actually, one more follow-up. Is there a way to simply not place a view or have it hidden? Imagine a coverflow style view where you only want to show a small set of subviews.

üëÄ Eryn
Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:20:45

*Thread Reply:* You interact with the subviews from within the layout protocol via the subview proxies that you get as input. This lets you do things like propose a size or place the view, but not perform arbitrary operations on the view, or apply arbitrary modifiers. If there‚Äôs something specific that you‚Äôd like to do but can‚Äôt, please do file a feedback with your use case.

üëç Ryan
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:55:05

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:08:26

@Christopher asked > When is onAppear/onDisappear called? How do they compare to the UIKit equivalents of did/willAppear?

üëç Malcolm
Paul B (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:09:29

*Thread Reply:* hi, the framework makes no guarantees on the specific timeframes on when these methods are called, but you can be sure that onAppear will always be called before the view is visible to the user and onDisappear will never be called while the view is on screen.

Paul B (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:10:21

*Thread Reply:* We have recently updated the documentation for these methods online to clarify these details; see https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/AnyView/onAppear(perform:) and https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/AnyView/onDisappear(perform:)

Paul B (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:11:35

*Thread Reply:* in terms of a comparison to UIKit, there is not a direct parallel. The UIKit methods are invoked specifically around when views become visible/not visible to the user, whereas the SwiftUI calls are tied more to when the views are constructed/torn down, rather than visually presented.

üëÜ:skin_tone_5: Paris P (Apple)
üíØ Paris P (Apple)
üëç Juan, Christopher, Eduardo
üëÜ Viennarz
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:08:33

Adrian asked: > ‚ÄúUsing @State and @Environment works e.g. in ButtonStyle even though it‚Äôs not a View. I‚Äôm looking to implement a similar API technique in my framework to let users style my custom components. However, I can‚Äôt get @State and @Environment to automatically work in my custom style structs. What is the recommended way to replicate this behavior so that I can provide such natural-feeling styling API for my custom framework components?

Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:12:28

*Thread Reply:* We don‚Äôt currently support extending our property wrapper APIs like @State and @Environment outside of how they are used in SwiftUI.

Muthuveerappan
2022-06-08 01:17:08

*Thread Reply:* @Matt R (Apple) I have a child view which has a @StateObject var MyModel but the initialiser to MyModel accepts a parameter passed from the parent view. How do I create MyModel in the initialiser of the child view or is there an alternate way?

John
2022-06-08 01:20:05

*Thread Reply:* My memory on this is poor but does SwiftUI synthetize an init to pass in stateObject params from the parent?

Radu
2022-06-08 01:20:47

*Thread Reply:* To the original poster: not an Apple engineer, but I‚Äôve build something similar in the past by making the struct conform to DynamicProperty . SwiftUI will pass through all DynamicProperty members recursively and inject dependencies (i.e. @Environment and @State ) before calling body .

üëç Michael
Adrian
2022-06-08 01:20:57

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for your answer, Matt! I‚Äôm working on a closed-source framework (PSPDFKit) that aims to provide SwiftUI (and UIKit) APIs that feel like first-class citizens, and the ‚Äúview style‚Äù technique that SwiftUI utilizes would be extremely valuable for me to let the users of our framework customize specific parts of components, much like e.g. using ToogleStyle.

I actually made some progress on this but I can‚Äôt share more publicly. I guess this would be a good Lab topic.

Adrian
2022-06-08 01:21:47

*Thread Reply:* (Oh I see you edited out the question about sharing more about the context.)

Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:21:50

*Thread Reply:* Yes this would be a great topic to request a lab for!

üëÄ Adrian
Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:23:06

*Thread Reply:* @Radu note that custom types conforming to DynamicProperty will only work if values of those types are stored within views or other SwiftUI types that generally support dynamic properties like @State and @Environment.

Radu
2022-06-08 01:25:47

*Thread Reply:* @Matt R (Apple) Ah, yes of course, I assumed that was given, outside of it would make little sense. Sorry for bringing a bit of confusion to the table! üòÖ

Adrian
2022-06-08 01:26:17

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, Matt! I‚Äôll be sure to request a lab. üòá Looking forward to learning more about this, I‚Äôm super excited about adopting modern SwiftUI techniques as a framework vendor (which is not that popular of a use case it seems!)

Jordan
2022-06-08 01:26:21

*Thread Reply:* @Adrian I've done something similar for other closed source things. The technique I am using revolves around creating a protocol/configuration (similar to what you'd find in ButtonStyle definition) and then injecting it into the EnvironmentValues via a custom value type conforming to EnvironmentKey. Then the component (e.g. Button for the purposes of this description) would internally grab the environment set (via @Environment(\.buttonStyle) private var buttonStyle)

You'd then just pass the configuration you build into the make** functions you create as needed.

Hope that makes sense. I've really enjoyed this technique in the components I've built.

üôå Chang
Muthuveerappan
2022-06-08 01:29:10

*Thread Reply:* Since StateObject(wrappedValue:) is not supposed to be called directly, the workaround i have found is every time my StateObject tends to depend on some parameter from parent view, I have used an ObservedObject (instead of a StateObject) and passed the ObservedObject from the parent view

Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:32:04

*Thread Reply:* @Jordan‚Äôs technique is an effective way to implement a similar pattern

Adrian
2022-06-08 01:32:08

*Thread Reply:* @Radu I got more or less as far as you described but I had troubles nesting DynamicProperty and controlling where exactly do they inherit the Environment from. @Jordan Thanks for sharing this! I have a similar infrastructure in place but my question was about using dynamic properties like @State directly in the structs conforming to MyCustomStyle protocol.

Jordan
2022-06-08 01:32:21

*Thread Reply:* and to dive a little more down for the State/Environment part of it, I would just pass those through the configuration struct if a style would need it (do this for passing things like isEnabled down)

similar to how ButtonStyleConfiguration has isPressed as a value

Adrian
2022-06-08 01:34:16

*Thread Reply:* Yes, this would come in the Configuration parameter of a makeBody(configuration:) -&gt; some View function.

Adrian
2022-06-08 01:38:37

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the discussion and suggestions! Feels like the most active question thread in the entire Q&A! üòÑ

üôå Jordan
Adrian
2022-06-08 01:39:26

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôll leave my specific questions and intricate details for a lab request to not take any more time from answering the questions of others.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:39:39

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the interesting question!

‚ù§Ô∏è Adrian
Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:39:54

*Thread Reply:* Great question Adrian, thanks for the discussion!

Evelyn R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:10:45

We‚Äôve been getting some questions regarding the new previews experience where each preview is given its own tab, and folks are wondering if there is a way to instead have multiple previews in the same tab.

Evelyn R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:15:44

*Thread Reply:* @Chris J (Apple), can you take this one. üí´

Chris J (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:19:14

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, Evelyn!

Each view in the PreviewProvider now shows in its own tab. If the individual views are differently configured rows for a list or can be combined in a VStack then a single preview could be used for seeing the different configurations. We'd love feedback if you have a unique case that you don't think is covered by the current solutions!

Evelyn R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:15:02

We‚Äôve been seeing some confusion regarding the behavior of the .previewLayout modifier in the new previews experience which we wanted to address.

Chris J (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:21:12

*Thread Reply:* the .previewLayout modifier does indeed still work, but like previous releases it does not affect the live preview which means you'd need to switch to the new Selectable mode to see its effect.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:35:27

@Anil Abraham asked > Is it possible to have a presented view that switches between the popover/sheet presentation styles depending on the size class (i.e., sheet in compact, popover in regular)?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:35:38

*Thread Reply:* Yes! You can do this by creating a custom view modifier that uses looks at the UserInterfaceSizeClass. Custom modifiers are great for conditional combinations of other modifiers, views, etc. and this is a perfect use case üôÇ

üëç Michael
Anil Abraham
2022-06-08 01:36:33

*Thread Reply:* Brilliant, thank you!

Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:38:08

*Thread Reply:* We have an example of this use case in the BookClub sample app, in ProgressEditor.swift.

üëç Michael
Anil Abraham
2022-06-08 02:01:57

*Thread Reply:* Doing it this way, the popover/sheet disappears when the size class changes from regular to compact (though not the other way around) due to window resizing on iPad. Does this seem like a framework bug or something I've overlooked?

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:37:56

@Lior asked > FWIK it's a good practice to have state changes the deeper in the view hierarchy as you can get, in order to avoid redundant redraws. Are there any best practices to achieve that besides breaking views down to tiny elements and composing them together?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:39:02

*Thread Reply:* The right way to structure your state varies by app.

I‚Äôm interested in understanding your specific use case. Are you asking this when using @State or ObservableObject?

Lior
2022-06-08 01:41:45

*Thread Reply:* Both actually. My use case involves a ViewModel which has @Published variables, together with diff element which is kind of a half drawer that involves @State for it's open/closed state.

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:46:50

*Thread Reply:* For State, I would generally recommend defining it at the level where you are going to use it.

For your ViewModel it could be useful to break your model into multiple ObservableObject that are specific to a specific functionality (like a cell, or a single screen). But I would avoid prematurely breaking you model into very small pieces.

SwiftUI does diff your view and will only re-render if it detects that something has changed.

üëç Lior, Michael, Bruno
Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:49:49

*Thread Reply:* ‚Ä¢ Everything suggested in the Demystify SwiftUI Session from a year or two back is definitely useful ‚Ä¢ Keeping Identifiers separate from values is recommended generally (but not a hard and fast rule), especially in Navigation APIs.

üëç Lior, Lee, Bruno
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:38:04

@Greg asked > Are there any types of macos apps or interfaces where you would still recommend using appkit rather than swiftui? > > I'm yet to invest the considerable amount of time learning swiftui and I keep reading mentions of people saying it's still a mixed bag for macos development, so I don't want to potentially waste time. Thanks!

Taylor K (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:39:39

*Thread Reply:* Good question! Across all platforms, we‚Äôd recommend comparing your needs to what SwiftUI provides (so no hard rules/recommendations) ‚Äî and keeping in mind that you can adopt SwiftUI incrementally.

Within Apple‚Äôs own apps on macOS, we‚Äôre ourselves using the full spectrum of approaches. From just a specific view/views in an app, e.g. in Mail, iWork, Keychain Access; to an entire portion of the UI or a new feature, e.g. in Notes, Photos, Xcode; and all the way to the majority of an application, e.g. Control Center, Font Book, System Settings.

But in the end, I‚Äôd recommend starting with a part you‚Äôre comfortable with and building up from there! You should look at SwiftUI as another tool in your toolset in enabling you to build the best apps you can.

üëç Kim, Greg, Michael, Kun, Lee, Alexey, Simon, Melvin
Greg
2022-06-08 01:46:02

*Thread Reply:* Great answer. Thanks.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:39:37

@Peter asked > When using the new MenuBarExtra in window style is it possible to control the width and maximum height of the content window?

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:41:46

*Thread Reply:* Hi - great question. The window size should be derived from the content provided to it, though we do impose a minimum and maximum on the resulting size. If you are seeing unexpected behavior in this area, please do file a feedback with a sample to reproduce it, and we can take a look.

Peter
2022-06-08 01:44:03

*Thread Reply:* I experience a pretty large minimum width and a pretty small maximum height. I'll file a feedback with a project.

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:41:44

We realize that it can be a little tricky to know how far exactly you can push those beautiful text transitions. Have you tried this out and seen otherwise?

Bardia
2022-06-08 22:21:59

Basically it animates perfectly back-and-forth when both text are visible on a single line.

However, when the one text goes over two lines ‚Äì due to larger text size for example ‚Äì and me allowing it to (via fixedSize(vertical: true)), this causes the animation in either direction to not be fluid (best demonstrated in the video).

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:54:27

@Josh asked > When creating a MenuBarExtra, is it possible to create something that runs on its own, separate from the parent app? I have an app that users can save data to by means of various app extensions. If the app is closed, however, those changes don't get synced to CloudKit. I was thinking of having a menu bar app that would essentially be my workaround: always listening, always active. Can a MenuBarExtra do that for me?

üëÄ John
Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:56:57

*Thread Reply:* Hi - you can certainly define a SwiftUI App with only a MenuBarExtra Scene. If your app should not show a Dock icon, that will require some changes to the Info.plist file, which should be noted in the documentation for MenuBarExtra

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:58:24

*Thread Reply:* See https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/menubarextra

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:58:24

*Thread Reply:* Posting that bit of documentation here as well: > For apps that only show in the menu bar, a common behavior is for the app to not display its icon in either the Dock or the application switcher. To enable this behavior, set the LSUIElement flag in your app‚Äôs Info.plist file to true.

Josh
2022-06-08 01:59:39

*Thread Reply:* Good to know. So it sounds like I would want to create a separate, MenuBarExtra-only app.

Can I bundle that with my Mac app on the App Store?

2022-06-08 02:05:38

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:56:08

@Randy asked > Are Deep Links possible in SwiftUI? > > If so, does it work well? > > Are there any limitations vs what is possible in UIKit?

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:57:13

*Thread Reply:* Check out the SwiftUI Cookbook for Navigation session and the What's New in SwiftUI session for 2 examples of deep links

üëç Uwe
Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:58:07

*Thread Reply:* They are indeed possible, and we think they work pretty well üòâ Of course, there's a lot of routing to consider with any app ‚Äî for instance if your deep link is behind some authentication token, you'll need to do the extra work there.

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:59:15

*Thread Reply:* The general idea is that a deep link is certain destinations presented ‚Äî in order ‚Äî on a navigation stack, and with this years' new APIs you can have full control over what is on the navigation stack.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:59:44

@Randy asked > What architecture is recommended for Enterprise apps when using SwiftUI? > > For instance: Coordinator Pattern, Dependency Injection Containers, etc.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 02:00:03

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the question!

One of the strengths of SwiftUI as a framework is that it works well with a variety of architectures.

We might be opinionated about API design üôÇ, but we want you to have the flexibility to design the data model that works best for your app.

The particular data model of any individual app depends on the domain of that app. For example, a car rental app might have a very different architecture from a news reader app.

Randy
2022-06-08 02:01:19

*Thread Reply:* Can you recommend a website that provides various examples of architecture using SwiftUI?

Christian
2022-06-08 02:02:11

*Thread Reply:* One challenge I‚Äôve come across is that the coordinator pattern doesn‚Äôt translate well to SwiftUI. You will often have NavigationLinks in your views, whereas the coordinator pattern wants to separate that logic from the view itself.

But this years NavigationStack is going to make new coordinator-like patterns much easier to implement. I‚Äôm curious to experiment with that this week.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 02:01:32

@Lior asked > Is it possible in general to use TimelineView as a "global clock" that can be synced by all the devices (that use the app) in order to display/show something at the same exact time? (if so, what precision should be expect?)

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 02:01:46

*Thread Reply:* While TimelineView can be used to update views at a specific point in time, it isn‚Äôt designed specifically for cross-device synchronization. You may be able to use it for that kind of use case, but it wouldn‚Äôt provide any better precision than using a Timer or other scheduling mechanism

üëç Lior, Michael
Evelyn R (Apple)
2022-06-08 02:05:36

We hope you continue the fun for the rest of the activities we have planned throughout the week! ü•≥

üëç Brendan
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:11:09

*Thread Reply:* Dragging and dropping between cells of a Grid would be a higher level component you'd want to build on top of the Grid layout

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:11:32

*Thread Reply:* Grid is eager, so putting it in a ScrollView can create performance issues, unless you‚Äôre certain the number of items is small.

*Thread Reply:* When Layout will be calculated? From UIKit experience, sizeThatFits fail to calculate size on viewDidLoad

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:22:26

*Thread Reply:* Layout participates in SwiftUI‚Äôs general update system. It will be computed when any state affecting the layout changes.

üëç Daiki, Ran

*Thread Reply:* Layout is eager.

Daiki
2022-06-08 18:23:24

*Thread Reply:* > Layout participates in SwiftUI‚Äôs general update system. It will be computed when any state affecting the layout changes. Ah..Yes! That‚Äôs SwiftUIüòÑ

Robert
2022-06-08 18:24:02

*Thread Reply:* is eager the opposite of lazy?

üëÄ Ran
Anil Abraham
2022-06-08 18:24:23

*Thread Reply:* Why are the subviews being placed with a y position of the layout‚Äôs midY rather than minY?

Brendan
2022-06-08 18:24:37

*Thread Reply:* It would seem that all this code for determining the largest width subview should perhaps just be a modifier on HStack and VStack?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:24:39

*Thread Reply:* Yes, sorry. Eager means computed in advance. Lazy means computed only when needed.

üëç Robert, Ran
Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:24:41

*Thread Reply:* Because they were anchored by their center point

üëç Anil Abraham

üëç Jeannine, Kenneth, Jordan, Chang, Alexey

2022-06-08 18:26:20

*Thread Reply:* Exactly it can reduce the use of GeometryReader

üéâ Ron, Lukas, Alexey
Jordan
2022-06-08 18:29:28

*Thread Reply:* GeometryReader definitely felt like that hammer we had to use for things other than nails. Will be very happy to remove some of that code.

Olivier
2022-06-08 18:29:29

*Thread Reply:* Follow-up to my lazy loading question: I suppose it is not recommended to use Layout with thousands of subviews in a ScrollView because it would hurt performances, right?

Harlan
2022-06-08 18:29:35

*Thread Reply:* The GeometryReader + preference keys pattern frequently led to issues like layout cycles and too-frequent updates. I am also very glad to see that Layout obviates the need for many GeometryReaders.

üéâ Lukas, Ran
Michael
2022-06-08 18:30:16

*Thread Reply:* That went by a bit quick - How many layouts can you have in AnyLayout?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:30:44

*Thread Reply:* Note: AnyLayout != ViewThatFits

Harlan
2022-06-08 18:30:45

*Thread Reply:* AnyLayout erases just one layout, but you can dynamically switch between them while preserving animations and State. You can switch between any number of layouts.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:31:17

*Thread Reply:* Olivier, yes, you‚Äôd likely run into performance issues.

üëç Olivier, Harlan, Daiki
Michael
2022-06-08 18:32:19

*Thread Reply:* So - AnyLayout could be user selectable?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:26:10

Ryan

*Thread Reply:* I assume the contents of each Layout in ViewThatFits won‚Äôt share the same state and they won‚Äôt animate between states as they‚Äôre different views with different ids?

Daiki
2022-06-08 18:29:43

*Thread Reply:* I need .automatic() modifier with AI solution.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:30:13

*Thread Reply:* Ya the mental model for ViewThatFits is that all the children have different identity

Ryan
2022-06-08 18:30:45

*Thread Reply:* It seems like an odd approach given the push to make changes to modifiers instead of multiple copies of the same view in the past

Harlan
2022-06-08 18:31:35

*Thread Reply:* AnyLayout does not require making copies of the same view, rather it is a concrete view that dispatches the layout behavior to a type-erased layout.

Ryan
2022-06-08 18:32:01

*Thread Reply:* I get AnyLayout does that. I was talking about ViewThatFits

Ryan
2022-06-08 18:32:49

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôd like a way to use the ‚Äúdoes it fit‚Äù logic to toggle between AnyLayout

Ryan
2022-06-08 18:33:06

*Thread Reply:* while keeping the child views the same

Anil Abraham
2022-06-08 18:35:00

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, it would be useful to have a way of animating between different layouts based on which fits, in case the size of the container changes (due to a window resize or something)

‚úÖ Jason

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:36:13

@Michael asked > S0 - AnyLayout could be user selectable (if selection changed @State)?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:36:47

*Thread Reply:* Yes! As Paul showed in the video any State or property can drive conditional logic to choose between different Layouts using AnyLayout

Michael
2022-06-08 18:38:22

*Thread Reply:* That is very powerful! Gets rid of all sorts of Case and If views üòÄ

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:37:04

@Kevin asked > Can a column span partial columns in Grid? i.e. If I have 8 items in a three column Grid, I want the last row to have two cells that are 1¬Ω columns each.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:38:22

*Thread Reply:* The column spanning uses an integer, but you could try doubling the number of columns you're using

Kevin
2022-06-08 18:39:31

*Thread Reply:* Hmm‚Ä¶ that could work, thanks!

Ryan
2022-06-08 18:42:12

*Thread Reply:* Using integer multiples works really well. If you want one view to be 3/5 of the width and the other 2/5 you just use 3 and 2 on each (assuming they each take all available space)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:37:53

@Andrew asked > Can I use custom layout to create a hierarchical tree map/view of rectangular boxes of data items connected with lines?

Andrew
2022-06-08 18:38:09

*Thread Reply:* None

Image from iOS
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:38:10

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a fascinating question, Andrew!

üòä Andrew, Shannon
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:38:33

*Thread Reply:* Layout could readily handle positioning the boxes.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:38:48

*Thread Reply:* The lines would be the interesting part.

Lior
2022-06-08 18:39:12

*Thread Reply:* Sounds like a good challenge üôÇ

Andrew
2022-06-08 18:39:31

*Thread Reply:* I'm just not sure of any other way to do this currently for an app view I want to do.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:39:33

*Thread Reply:* You might experiment with using the layout values to route information.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:41:07

*Thread Reply:* You could also experiment with using Canvas to do the drawing, though that‚Äôs a low-level approach that wouldn‚Äôt give you accessibility out of the box. Check out the accessibilityRepresentation modifier for that.

üëç Andrew
Andrew
2022-06-08 18:41:31

*Thread Reply:* Any ideas on how to ‚Äúroute‚Äù?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:42:48

*Thread Reply:* Ultimately, that‚Äôs ‚Äújust‚Äù math. There are a few open source frameworks for diagram drawing. You might be able to see what algorithms they are using.

‚úÖ Andrew
Kevin
2022-06-08 18:43:10

*Thread Reply:* Maybe alternate row of boxes & row of custom Paths? Use the layout info from the boxes to feed the custom Paths.

üëç Andrew
Chang
2022-06-08 18:43:34

*Thread Reply:* In fact you can do it using SwiftUI 2021. objc.io made a series of video to demo how to draw tree image using pure SwiftUI (sorry for 3rd-party resource) https://talk.objc.io/episodes/S01E293-advanced-alignment-part-3

talk.objc.io
Advanced Alignment (Part 3)
We use type-level programming to specify the alignment for each level of the tree diagram separately.
Original URL: https://talk.objc.io/episodes/S01E293-advanced-alignment-part-3
‚úÖ Ratnesh, Vidunan
üëç Andrew
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:42:57

@Ryan asked > Do LayoutValueKey values travel up through nested Layouts? Also, how are they different from PreferenceKey?

üëç Javier
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:43:45

*Thread Reply:* LayoutValueKeys only travel up to the nearest Layout container

Ryan
2022-06-08 18:43:58

*Thread Reply:* OK, good to know

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:44:58

*Thread Reply:* One reason for this is for Layout to facilitate building of encapsulations that can be composed without having unanticipated effects on the other views that surround it

üëç Ryan, Lee, Vidunan, Melvin
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:45:55

@Lukas asked > Do all system stacks implement the Layout protocol for use in AnyLayout? Is this documented anywhere?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:46:35

*Thread Reply:* The goal is for as many system provided layouts to conform to the Layout protocol as possible, including the stacks.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:46:57

*Thread Reply:* You can find what protocols a type conforms to in the developer documentation

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:47:10

*Thread Reply:* Yup, scroll down on this page: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/hstack

üéâ Lukas, Robert, Rahul
Lukas
2022-06-08 18:47:52

*Thread Reply:* Thanks!

2022-06-08 18:49:01

*Thread Reply:* Flow layouts are great for it. There‚Äôs a good example in the Food Truck sample app.

üëç Kyle M (Apple)

2022-06-08 18:49:06
