In the State of the Union we mentioned Flow and Radial layouts as good examples

üëç Evgheni
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:49:31

*Thread Reply:* A custom layout can be a good fit if there's something super custom in your app

Jan
2022-06-08 18:49:44

*Thread Reply:* I am thinking of a dynamic layout case for seating order around tables. User could create a new Table, specify if the table is rectangular, oval or circular, and specify the number of guests at each side. We could then get a layout for the table as specified, and the user can fill in the guests. In code terms, this could mean that the specific layout should be created dynamically. Would something like this be possible?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:49:59

*Thread Reply:* It's an even better fit for building a generic layout container that you can reuse across your app (like Flow referenced above)

üöÄ Evgheni
Ryan
2022-06-08 18:50:14

*Thread Reply:* Or if you like bee hives‚Ä¶ https://twitter.com/ryanlintott/status/1534367196251574272

üêù Jan, Daiki, Ryan, Evgheni, Josh
Taylor K (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:52:30

*Thread Reply:* Even really subtle, nuanced layouts can bring a little extra level of polish ‚Äî plus be composed together! For higher level features like the new form style on macOS we‚Äôre using several small custom layouts to get it to perfectly match what the design specs described

üëç Ryan
Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:52:45

*Thread Reply:* Jan, that sort of thing is definitely possible! In fact, in the what's new in SwiftUI talk, they show an example of a layout which is very similar to what you‚Äôre describing to make a seating chart for SwiftUI‚Äôs birthday party!

üöÄ Jan, Ran

2022-06-08 18:53:48

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:48:20

@Ryan asked > Is there a way to build a Layout that would effect each child view with ViewModifiers? Let's say I always want to style the first view one way and the second another.

üëÄ Chang, Ladislav
üëç Javier
Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:50:22

*Thread Reply:* LayoutValueKey allows you to pass information from your view hierarchy along to layout, but please note that layout can't use this information to make style changes to the view, only to determine its layout.

The information is passed through to layout through layout proxies, so the original view isn't accessible from the layout protocol.

Ryan
2022-06-08 18:51:46

*Thread Reply:* I guess what I‚Äôm looking for is a way to apply modifiers to a Group that would only apply to specific subview indexes. It would only need to apply in one direction. I guess it‚Äôs time to write another Feedback.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:55:31

@Adrien asked > Why would anyone use observable object instead of state object?

üëÄ Cristina
Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:57:22

*Thread Reply:* You might want to use @ObservedObject if the lifecycle of your model is not owned by your view.

An example is if you are using UIHostingConfiguration and you have your model owned by UIKit in a UIViewController and just passed to a SwiftUI cell.

:gratitude_thank_you: Cristina
Lowell
2022-06-08 18:58:54

*Thread Reply:* Also @Published properties in ObservableObjects use Combine publishers, which can have their own basket of use cases too

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:03:32

*Thread Reply:* Also, in general you want to use @StateObject in a parent view, and if you pass the same ObservableObject instance to child views you can use just @ObservedObject.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:56:31

@Chang asked > ViewModifier question: > What‚Äôs the difference between a custom ViewModifier (without DynamicProperty) that uses some built-in modifiers in body(content:), and a custom View extension func that just use those built-in modifiers? > > Similarly, what‚Äôs the difference between a custom ViewModifier with some DynamicProperty and a custom View with some DynamicProperty (also has a @ViewBuilder content property to receive content to modify) ? I think two have the same render result and behavior.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:57:23

*Thread Reply:* Because of the way a ViewModifier is expressed, the engine knows it's not changing the content passed in and can apply performance optimizations (compared to just an extension on View)

üí° Ryan
üôå Chang
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:57:03

@Michael asked > A bit off topic to Grids / Layouts but not to Customization - Is there any way in SwiftUI to create multiple Windows (or Window like things) on Mac (and maybe iPad) or Pages on iOS?

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:58:12

*Thread Reply:* Hi - thanks for the question! You can certainly compose the different Scene types available in your App to create the functionality you'd like. For instance a WindowGroup and a Window or DocumentGroup and a WindowGroup, etc.

Jan
2022-06-08 18:58:48

*Thread Reply:* hey, I was gonna ask that question later today üòÇ Right now we need to use UIKit lifecycle if we want to show HUD that overlays the entire app. For example: https://www.fivestars.blog/articles/swiftui-windows/ it would be really useful to be able to do this without relying on SceneDelegate!

Cristina
2022-06-08 19:01:59

*Thread Reply:* I have the same question as well, what would be the recommended way to do what @Jan says? I thought about using the overlay modifier on the root view of the app but what if there are presented views?

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:04:45

*Thread Reply:* Something like what is in that blog post is likely worth a feedback for an enhancement request. Thanks!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:00:31

@Samuel asked > Is there a way to use a capacity Gauge outside of the lock screen?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:05:00

*Thread Reply:* Yes! Gauge is usable outside of the Lock Screen, and also has a whole host of new styles! I would take a look at the linearCapacity, accessoryLinearCapacity, and accessoryCircularCapacity styles. Please note though that gauge styles prefixed with ‚Äúaccessory‚Äù are really intended to appear in contexts like the Lock Screen / widgets, or some similar design context within your app proper, so please give careful consideration to where you use them.

üëç Samuel
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:00:31

@Cindy asked > I implemented the new searchable APIS yesterday. One issue I have is that when suggestions are presented, it completely blocks out the entire search view. I'm wanting to implement something similar to the Photos search feature where you can see a small box at the top with search suggestions, while also display existing results. Is there a way to accomplish this with searchable?

Harry L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:02:06

*Thread Reply:* If you‚Äôd like search suggestions to be rendered inline your results, you should consider them as part of your results and not provide any suggestion views to the searchable modifier.

Note though that in iOS 16.0, for a regular width size class, a search bar that is displayed in the trailing navigation bar will display suggestions in a menu rather than over the main content like on macOS. Take a look at the SearchSuggestionsPlacement type and searchSuggestions(_:in:) modifier for customizing your UI around this behavior.

ü§ù Cindy

2022-06-08 19:01:44

However, the tap targets for the pickers are all off by some factor, such that if I try to scroll to the right of the middle of a picker, it actually scrolls the picker to the right instead. Is this a known issue? Is there a workaround?

2022-06-08 19:02:20

2022-06-08 19:04:32

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:04:38

@Ryan asked > ViewThatFits feels very convenient but I'm concerned about making copies of the same content for each layout option. I assume a custom layout would be required to achieve this?

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:05:02

*Thread Reply:* ViewThatFits is a convenience that might not be appropriate if you need something with animated transitions, or in general something with more complex behavior.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:28:46

@Vincent asked > Can the new Charts API allow for scrolling? similar to the health app's charts

üëÄ Chang
‚ûï Martin, Cristina, Alexander
Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:30:27

*Thread Reply:* Sorry, late answer forgot to hit send: Yes, charts should behave just like any other view in this regard. though you may have to set explicit frames on the chart to specify how big (wide? tall?) you want it to be

Evelyn R (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:34:10

*Thread Reply:* We just couldn‚Äôt wait till the next Q&A, Ok I promise we are done now!!! ü§ì

üôè Lior
üòÑ Vincent
Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:57:52

*Thread Reply:* Hey @Vincent I just realized the health app chart does scrolling that keeps the y-axis stationary, that specifically isn't supported, but we've received a few requests about this, but few feedbacks. So if you file a feedback for the Charts team, we'd appreciate it

We‚Äôd love to hear more about your use case and please do file a feedback with more details so that we can take it into consideration for the future.

Bardia
2022-06-08 22:24:15

*Thread Reply:* Yep, it‚Äôs on iOS that I‚Äôm referring to. I will, okay! The use case is basically wanting to create a bespoke experience that involves using a custom font (Avenir Next). It‚Äôs inconsistent/less cohesive if controls such as menus use a different font.

Paul B (Apple)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:06:49

@Jason asked > How does Layout interact with other view modifiers or constructs that can provide layout data, like offset, geometry reader, anchor preferences, etc? (For context I've got a card game-type view that currently lays out cards in columns all powered by GeometryReader and anchor preferences, because I need specific frame data when a user performs a drag gesture to drag a card over a region of the screen to perform logic. I'm wondering if it's possible to re-implement it in Layout, but I'm unclear about if it's possible to get at the anchor preference frame data.)

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:08:27

*Thread Reply:* A layout is only able to position its direct subviews.

It can be superior to GeometryReader because it's able to do that while also computing a sizeThatFits.

If you're trying to arrange things that are crossing parent-child boundaries, though, anchor preferences will likely still be necessary.

Jason
2022-06-08 22:12:16

*Thread Reply:* A Layout that contained and positioned all of my card subviews would therefore know their positions - and I imagine I could put those in the cache. I guess I'm wondering if there's a way my layout can provide that information out to my model layer when a drag gesture finishes?

Jason
2022-06-08 22:14:55

*Thread Reply:* More generally - can a Layout relay its layout information externally in some way? Or is that not possible?

Curt C (Apple)

*Thread Reply:* I believe it applies to the current view, so you can change the behavior at different levels of the hierarchy.

üëç Ruchish, Ilter

@Jakub asked > How do I actually apply Variable Color to an SF Symbol along with the percentage I want highlighted vs dimmed? Is there a SwiftUI modifier for this?

üëÄ Andrew, Alexey
Jacob X (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:09:35

*Thread Reply:* You can make a variable color symbol with: Image(systemName: "wifi", variableValue: signalStrength) It‚Äôs part of initializing the image, not a separate modifier you apply.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:10:21

@Cristian-Mihai asked > Hello! I am trying to create a new custom Layout. I would like to know how to access LayoutValueKeys from within a Layout.

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:10:50

*Thread Reply:* The documentation for the new layout API is fantastically written and should have all of the information you need to get up and running! It explains it far better than I could in a short question answer. You can check out the docs for LayoutValueKey here. It even has a walkthrough that shows you how to create, set, and retrieve keys!

https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/layoutvaluekey/

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:14:03

@Tom asked > Fairly new to Swift & SwiftUI. Curious if there are any changes to Core Data/SwiftUI integration this year. Using ManagedObjects with SwiftUI seems to results in View that know a lot about Models or Models that have a mix of business logic and view logic which can be confusing. Any suggested best practices for using Managed Objects with SwiftUI? > > I tried writing value type wrappers to do MVVM but that breaks down with relationships.

‚ûï Andrew, Lowell, Max, Christopher, Ilter
üëç Timothy, Collin, Max, Christopher, Alexey, S√©rgio, Moritz, Klayton
Jan
2022-06-08 22:17:42

*Thread Reply:* This is a topic that deserves its own WWDC üòÇ I really, really recommend Paul Hudson's videos on this. He helped me a lot with understanding the relationships between SwiftUI and Core Data. Especially important if you plan to use SectionedFetchRequest or generic FetchRequest ‚ö° There is still a lot of improvement to make Core Data more SwiftUI-esque, here's hoping for WWDC23 üòá

‚ûï Andrew
üëç Tom, Jeannine
Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:18:00

*Thread Reply:* Hi Tom, Great question. There were no additions to SwiftUI in regards to Core Data. However, we do have our CoreData Earthquakes sample app and all showing best practices with SwiftUI and background contexts.

üíØ Ilter, Yevhen
Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:19:00

*Thread Reply:* The former performs batch inserts and merges changes on a background thread, then publishes the changes to SwiftUI on the main thread.

üëç Tom
Tom
2022-06-08 22:19:45

*Thread Reply:* One place I am struggling with right now is providing the ability to edit an entity with the idea of "cancel" and "save".

Ilter
2022-06-08 22:21:39

For a very simple Core Data + List implementation, app crashes whenever an item is deleted from the List. It would be awesome if there was a guideline around more complex implementations.

üëÄ Paris P (Apple)
Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:21:55

*Thread Reply:* > One place I am struggling with right now is providing the ability to edit an entity with the idea of "cancel" and "save". This notion of edit propagation is described in the Landmarks app in the SwiftUI Tutorials

üëÄ Ilter, Tom
Tom
2022-06-08 22:23:27

Tom
2022-06-08 22:23:46

‚ù§Ô∏è Paris P (Apple)
Axel
2022-06-08 23:29:53

*Thread Reply:* @Paris P (Apple) I'm not sure we can compare the Landmark app based on Struct with an app using Core Data with objects in contexts. How can we use child contexts with SwiftUI? What would be the best approach to edit entities in a child context?

Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:33:41

*Thread Reply:* Great follow-up question, Axel. We don't have a sample today detailing this exact scenario, so you'll have to apply the same concepts from the Landmarks app to the merge flow shown in Earthquakes. I'd suggest requesting more samples via Feedback Assistant, though, so we can consider more opportunities to improve our learning resources.

Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:35:22

*Thread Reply:* To clarify, the Earthquakes sample uses private contexts to perform its batch inserts and merges the changes into the main context. So, that sample is a great place to start.

Axel
2022-06-08 23:47:07

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. I explored a lot these sample projects and took some inspiration. But they don't really cover UI edits made by a user. I'll fill some FB.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:16:06

@Ivan asked > Heya! I have a macOS app where I am attempting to 'tear off' certain SwiftUI views as floating free form windows. I've looked into some of the WindowGroup API, but it doesn't seem like it supports what I'm looking for. Essentially, I have N views of various sizes that can either be docked into a main window, or float above it. I'm running in to issues like sharing state between the docked version and the windowed one, as there seems to be a difference in the relationship between how a standard SwiftUI update bindings works for windows or views. Given that, what would be some ways that I could go about this method of 'docking / undocking' SwiftUI views, and keeping their state in tact? > > Thank you!

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:16:24

*Thread Reply:* Hi - this is really interesting! I'm not really sure we have any API that entirely fits your concept here, but I'd love to learn more. Can you speak to how you are accomplishing this at the moment? Also a feedback for this with any details you provide would be great!

‚ù§Ô∏è Ivan
Ivan
2022-06-08 22:29:16

*Thread Reply:* Absolutely! I‚Äôm doing this right now in my project at github.com/tikimcfee/LookAtThat.

Posting this now to respond to you, and will follow up real quick with a screenshot and a code snippet.

Ivan
2022-06-08 22:31:04

*Thread Reply:* None

Screen Shot 2022-06-08 at 1.30.27 PM.png
Screen Shot 2022-06-08 at 1.30.18 PM.png
Ivan
2022-06-08 22:32:28

*Thread Reply:* The key classes are all here:

https://github.com/tikimcfee/LookAtThat/tree/4dbe4a8f93f5dafd56752433df917352076da664/Interop/Views/FloatableView

Ivan
2022-06-08 22:34:09

*Thread Reply:* FloatableView swift basically takes some bindings to an enumerable state type (floating, docked), and then either presents the view directly as a child, or acts as an intermediary ‚Äòadapter‚Äô between the parent hosting view and a floating window. The window itself ends up as a separate instance of the view, but seems to be more or less functional since it still can participate in shared state updates.

The other classes, window delegate and the extensions, help construct and manage the window lifecycle a bit.

Ivan
2022-06-08 22:35:37

*Thread Reply:* The two things that are tricky are that the view is still technically bound to an EmptyView that lets the state remain active, and the window is its own ‚Äòthing‚Äô. It seems like there would be a way to sever that connection between the root view that owns the docked version of the view and the window (which is why I was really trying to consider WindowGroups), but I just couldn‚Äôt crack this one.

Ivan
2022-06-08 22:37:37

*Thread Reply:* And hey, is that feedback from the dev-feedback-app? If so, I‚Äôd be happy to share this and our discussion with it.

And since I was rude and forgot, thank you for taking your time to talk and take a look!

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:41:09

*Thread Reply:* Yep, there should be an app called Feedback Assistant that you can use. Any info you can put in there, like what you have above would certainly be useful.

Ivan
2022-06-08 22:47:12

*Thread Reply:* @Jeff R (Apple) Done! I have a fancy-pants ID too : FB10112377

üôè Jeff R (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:16:21

@Gero asked > Why does NavigationLink pre-render the destination when it's being rendered? I am loading Heart Rate data in my destination View and this slows down rendering significantly. What's a better pattern to prevent accidental pre-loading of data?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:16:41

*Thread Reply:* In general we discourage to do any expensive work in the init of a view. SwiftUI expects the creation of views to be cheap. We recommend doing any side effect or data loading with either .task or .onAppear.

üëç Alexey, Luke, Christopher
Gero
2022-06-08 22:19:15

*Thread Reply:* Even .onAppear ran last time I tried. Currently I am using this workaround from StackOverflow:

public struct NavigationLazyView&lt;Content: View&gt;: View { public let build: () -&gt; Content public init(_ build: @autoclosure @escaping () -&gt; Content) { self.build = build } public var body: Content { build() } }

Gero
2022-06-08 22:19:41

*Thread Reply:* Starting loading of data in onAppear causes some time the user has to wait for the heart rate graph. Also not super desireable.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:21:50

*Thread Reply:* Check out the new NavigationStack. Inside that NavigationLinks can present values instead of views. The resulting view can then do work in onAppear or using task.

‚úÖ Gero
üëÄ Gero
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:17:02

@Adrien asked > When using UIHostingController, is it better to add it to the view controller hierarchy (with addChildViewController), or could we use its rootView and simply add it as a subView ?

üëÄ Alejandro, Ilter
Sara F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:19:02

*Thread Reply:* You want to always add a UIHostingController as a childViewController. // Add the hosting controller as a child view controller self.addChild(hostingController) self.view.addSubview(hostingController.view) hostingController.didMove(toParent: self) without the view controller relationship things that depend on the UIViewController hierarchy won‚Äôt work. Such as UIViewControllerRepresentable

Sara F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:20:43

*Thread Reply:* There are a few other types as well that depend on this relationship in their underlying representations so its best practice to add the parent/child relationship.

üôè Adrien
Ilter
2022-06-08 22:27:16

*Thread Reply:* I am building a design system implementation where I‚Äôm providing reusable components that other teams can simply build their features. I usually start with SwiftUI but this view controller relationship makes things very hard at times, especially if the view in question is complex. I believe there is NSHostingView on the Mac, I wish we had the same on iOS. For the time being, given the requirement, is there any recommendation to fulfill this requirement? For example, can we even use window‚Äôs rootViewController as a parent or is there a better way?

Sara F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:35:17

*Thread Reply:* yes the AppKit underlying infrastructure makes NSHostingView work while UIKit is not able to do so due to the hierarchy requirements. It depends on exactly what you are trying to build, but potentially you could make a reusable view controller that your teams can use instead depending on where the complexity is at. Parenting at the rootViewController would have issues with any navigation calls you might try to make in SwiftUI.

Ilter
2022-06-08 22:39:31

*Thread Reply:* Ah got it, thanks for clarifying. It is a little bit overhead to ask the teams to add a child view controller just for a button from the design system. üòÖ And it‚Äôs extra challenging if they are adding it to a UIView subclass down in the view hierarchy where they don‚Äôt have access to any view controller for example.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:17:02

@Lior asked > Should Layout work fine with UIKit-representable views?

üëÄ Alexey, Lucas
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:17:58

*Thread Reply:* Yes! To get more control over how UIViewControllerRepresentables size themselves in SwiftUI layout you may want to implement their new sizeThatFits method: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/uiviewcontrollerrepresentable/sizethatfits(_:uiviewcontroller:context:)-35p75

üôå Lior, Christopher
üôè Lior

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:17:53

@Joseph asked > While I was working with Canvas and rendering images, shapes, and text, I was trying to sort out if there was a way to get the offset for the baseline value from a ResolvedText. I wanted to align the text baseline to a visual element that I was drawing in canvas, and the only path I found to getting sizes of discrete elements was to resolve them and measure them - something akin to: > &gt; let captionedTextSampleSize: CGSize = context.resolve(Text(label).font(.caption)).measure(in: size) &gt; > > This hands back CGSize, which mostly worked for what I needed, but I'd really like to align to that baseline - and for that I need to determine an offset. Is there any public API to help me do that, or a technique I could use to get said offset that uses other frameworks or libraries?

Jacob X (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:18:57

*Thread Reply:* The GraphicsContext.ResolvedText type also has firstBaseline (and lastBaseline) methods. So you can do something like: let baseline = context.resolve(myText).firstBaseline(in: size)

Joseph
2022-06-08 22:19:22

*Thread Reply:* :face_palm: I totally missed that. Thank you Jacob!!!!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:18:43

@Patrick asked > SwiftUI Mac specific question: > When using .contextMenu on a List , how can I find out what was actually selected? > When looking at Finder, the selected (=item on which the action should be performed on) is either the selection (1 or more) OR it is the item that has been right clicked on directly. > How can I replicate this behavior using SwiftUI?

Harry L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:20:34

*Thread Reply:* Check out the new context menu API that accepts a forSelectionType parameter. This passes the value of the selection into the modifier for you to act on.

List(selection: $selection) { ... } .contextMenu(forSelectionType: MySelection.self) { selection in // check selection } Be sure to match the type of your lists selection to the type you provide to the context menu modifier.

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:21:30

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/view/contextaction(forselectiontype:action:)

Patrick
2022-06-08 22:26:49

*Thread Reply:* That is awesome, thank you! Are there any plans to back port "smaller" API changes like this into macOS Monterey and earlier?

üëÄ Ilter

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:26:52

*Thread Reply:* The pattern when working with Xcode, is to (1) background the app in the simulator or on device, (2) wait 10 seconds for the system to do its backgrounding work, (3) kill the app using the Stop button in Xcode.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:27:12

*Thread Reply:* Then when you run the app again, it should use the saved value.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:20:12

@Timothy asked > Just starting out with SwiftUI. One of the things that is hard to get my head around is the following. In UIKit, I have a label that pulses (grows and shrinks) based on certain events, so I'd typically have an outlet to the label and a method 'pulse'. In SwiftUI, I accomplished the same by having a binding labelState which I change in the containing View. So while UIKit would have an outlet for multiple labels, in SwiftUI I'd have a binding state for each label. Is that typically the correct pattern?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:20:47

*Thread Reply:* That seems like a totally reasonable approach! Generally, when you have some value that you want to change in SwiftUI, you want to make sure that there‚Äôs a clear source of truth for that value. That source of truth can either be @State, or a property within an ObservableObject.

When you have a fixed number of controls, having a separate piece of state backing each of those controls is completely reasonable.

That said, the sources of truth you provide for your state should mirror your UI, so if you dynamically generate your labels from an array of data, you might then want to have an array of data as the source of truth state for your ui components. If you see that your sources of truth for your data mirror the structure of your UI, you‚Äôre probably on the right track üôÇ

Timothy
2022-06-08 22:22:13

*Thread Reply:* ok thanks. A bit of looking at the problem from a different axis.

‚ù§Ô∏è Sam L (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:22:20

@Petar asked > Using .buttonStyle(MyCustonStyle()) instead of MyCustomButton(...) is more SwiftUI-y. But why should I prefer one over the other (considering MyCustomButton uses MyCustonStyle under the hood)?

Franck N (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:22:52

*Thread Reply:* Hi Peter, We strongly recommend separating semantic controls and styles as it provides a lot more flexibility. For example, using the button style modifier will apply to the whole hierarchy, so if you decide you want specific parts of your app to use a different button style, you can just apply it to that specific hierarchy without changing the control itself.

With this approach you also get multi-platform behaviors for free.

‚≠ê Petar, Max, Chon
Kyle
2022-06-08 22:55:40

*Thread Reply:* My app‚Äôs design uses kerning on most of its buttons, but I can‚Äôt put that inside of my ButtonStyle because kerning is only available on Text, which ButtonStyleConfiguration.Label is not. I have a feedback open suggesting passing kerning through the environment (FB10020695).

In the meantime, do you have any suggestions on how to do this without having to separately use .kerning() on every button label?

Kyle
2022-06-08 23:14:15

*Thread Reply:* Moved out here üòÑ https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03HX19UNCQ/p1654722720194909

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:22:43

@Rob asked > My question is about some code in the SwiftUI Cookbook for Navigation session. Around 23 minutes in, Curt uses the task modifier to run an async for loop over the model's objectWillChange publisher. In the loop, he then accesses an @Published property of the model. But a @Published property fires the objectWillChange property before it updates its wrappedValue. Doesn't that mean that when the code accesses navModel.jsonData, it will get the out-of-date model values? Or is there some async magic that guarantees the loop body will not run until later after the objectWillChange publisher has finished publishing and the @Published property has updated its wrappedValue?

üëç Adrien, Chang
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:24:26

*Thread Reply:* Great question! Task schedules its body on the main actor, which is also where the view update happens. So objectWillChange enqueues the body of the for loop, but it‚Äôs enqueued behind the update of the data model.

üëç Rob, Max, Matthias, Edward, Mike
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:22:45

@Adrien asked > What is the advantage of using custom Symbols rather than SVG with template rendering mode? > The ability to programmatically change the colors of several layers? Any other reason?

Christopher
2022-06-08 22:23:43

*Thread Reply:* Inlining within Text is a nice benefit, but doesn't seem to work with custom multicolor symbols.

Jacob X (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:24:44

*Thread Reply:* In addition to the great color support, using a custom symbol also helps it better fit with text by growing with fonts, respecting bold text, and matching baselines.

2022-06-08 22:31:46

2022-06-08 22:33:24

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:27:58

@Philipp asked > SwiftUI on macOS question: Is there a way to position the windows when they are opened? In my app, the position of the next window always depend on the last, offset a bit to the right and down. So they are slowly crawling down the screen, which is not nice.

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:29:52

*Thread Reply:* Hi - thanks for the question! The cascading of windows is the default behavior for WindowGroup. We've also added a new Scene modifier - defaultPosition, which allows you to specify an initial position to use absent any previous state for the window. It takes a UnitPoint, so for example, it would be something like defaultPosition(.topTrailing). Did you have some other behavior in mind? It'd be great to get more info, if so.

Philipp
2022-06-08 22:32:12

*Thread Reply:* It would be nice if I could position a new window just beside the already open window, e.g. to the right or left, depending on the available space. The second window is a ‚Äúcompagnon‚Äù to the document, used for editing.

2022-06-08 22:33:10

*Thread Reply:* Ah, I see. That makes sense given your use case there. Would you mind filing a feedback for an enhancement?

üëç Philipp
Philipp
2022-06-08 22:33:20

*Thread Reply:* So I have currently a DocumentGroup and a WindowGroup . The WindowGroup instance would have a one-to-one relation to an open document.

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:34:25

*Thread Reply:* Ok. Please include those details in the feedback, its definitely helpful when we are designing APIs

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:29:09

@Petar asked > What are good tells that I should use implicit vs explicit animations in SwiftUI?

Jacob X (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:32:29

*Thread Reply:* I usually default to withAnimation to set up animations based on when a change occurs. That way, whatever UI changes as a result will implicitly be animated.

In some cases, View.animation is useful when you have a certain view or view hierarchy you always want to change with an animation, regardless of what triggered it. A good example is the knob of a Switch: it should just always animate when it changes. (And make sure to pass an appropriate value, like .animation(myAnimation, value: mySwitchValue), so that you only animate when the property you care about changes, and don‚Äôt accidentally animate too often.)

‚≠ê Petar
Petar
2022-06-08 22:45:59

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for your reply Jacob I‚Äôve been having some difficulties deciding on best approaches especially when creating reusable components with baked in behaviours. This might be stretching it, but this is a gist that lays out my problem: https://gist.github.com/kanevP/a9d54f5c60eddabca000b1a45a59e70b Would love to hear your thoughts on the different animation usages.

2022-06-08 22:30:01

Mark E (Apple)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:30:35

@Joshua asked > In a WWDC20 session "Data Essentials in SwiftUI" there's a point in the video where the presenter touches on using a single data model that can have multiple ObservableObject projections to target SwiftUI updates to specific views. How can I achieve this?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:30:42

*Thread Reply:* The exact solution really depend on your data model but its can simply be as having a model that contains a bunch of properties where each of these type is an ObservableObject; or you could have a function that given an identifier return you the ObservableObject that corresponds to that id.

What we wanted to get across was that you want and you can scope your ObservableObject to specific screen of functionality of your app.

üôá Joshua
Joshua
2022-06-08 22:34:41

*Thread Reply:* I think I understand, thank you @Luca B (Apple)!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:31:13

@Alexandre asked > In our app, we can push a view containing a custom view above the navigation bar. We achieved it by using a NavigationView inside a NavigationView (displaying a custom view with the back button hidden). > > Is it possible to have a custom view above the navigation bar with NavigationStack? Is it possible to use a similar workaround?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:32:26

*Thread Reply:* Nested navigation stacks don‚Äôt compose the same way. An inner navigation stack is effectively a no-op; it doesn‚Äôt add anything and any path bound to it should be ignored.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:32:52

*Thread Reply:* Are you trying to achieve something like a very tall navigation bar?

2022-06-08 22:33:16

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôd love a Feedback with details of your use case!

2022-06-08 23:02:55

I would love to achieve the same effect with NavigationStack

‚ù§Ô∏è Curt C (Apple)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:33:00

@Lior asked > Question regarding the SwiftUI Instrument: > Is there a value of avg. duration that no View's body should go above when rendering for avoiding performance issues/hitches ?

Harry L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:35:49

*Thread Reply:* View‚Äôs body properties should be cheap and avoid any potentially expensive work. If there are things you need in your views body, its best to pre-compute that into a piece of state that you can pass your views.

Concretely, each frame has a hard deadline of generally 1/60s or 1/120s (depending on the refresh rate of the display) to render its content. Thats 8ms in the fastest case.

Thats for the entire screen to render its content though, not just your single view . So if any one view is taking more than a few ms to finish calling body, you‚Äôll run into issues.

If you‚Äôre using Swift concurrency to move work off the main thread, consider watching this session: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110350/

This is all mostly related to scrolling performance. Other kinds of things like app launch or navigation pushes will typically take longer than multiple frames to render, but those situations have different expectations around frame deadlines.

Apple Developer
Visualize and optimize Swift concurrency - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how you can optimize your app with the Swift Concurrency template in Instruments. We'll discuss common performance issues and show...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110350/
üôè Lior
üëç Lior
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:36:42

@Jan asked > We can now use .foregroundColor(.white.shadow(‚Ä¶)) on SFSymbols. Will this work with custom PNGs/SVGs as well?

‚ûï Christopher
Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:37:29

*Thread Reply:* foregroundStyles apply only to shapes, image masks, and text. If the Image is configured as a template, then foreground styles should be applied. If the image is non-template, they won't

Mirko
2022-06-08 22:38:23

*Thread Reply:* Yes if you set render as to template for your image asset

image.png
Jan
2022-06-08 22:38:48

*Thread Reply:* Excellent, thank you! üôè

Nick T (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:39:11

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Mirko! and thanks for the great question Jan

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:37:27

@Eric asked > Hi there, is there any way to get my offscreen nested StateObjects to not be deallocated when scrolled offscreen within a LazyStack? The only solution I've found is to "hoist" them to the top level of the LazyStack, e.g. within the Content of a ForEach, but that feels kinda clunky to have to do in every scenario‚Äîwondering if there's another option.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:38:02

*Thread Reply:* I think "hoisting" your state into an ancestor is your best bet here

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:38:53

*Thread Reply:* As an aside, StateObject is more commonly used with model objects and you generally don't want to tie your model object's lifecycle to the view

üëç Malcolm
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:39:23

*Thread Reply:* In the case of a model object it might make sense for an ancestor model object to be maintaining references to these children model objects

Ben
2022-06-08 22:42:39

*Thread Reply:* @Kyle M (Apple) What guarantees (if any) do we have about the longevity of a StateObject property on a view? Should I try to move view-owned objects to the root App struct and inject them via EnvironmentObject?

Ben
2022-06-08 22:44:58

*Thread Reply:* I've already run into issues when changing device orientation, with my view hierarchy being torn down and recreated, losing any ephemeral state

Eric
2022-06-08 22:45:41

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! Yes in this scenario it's effectively a State , just incidentally modeled as a StateObject for other reasons ‚Äî however we were finding that a State was getting reset as well back to the initial value as well in that same scenario. I assume that's expected as well?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:51:05

*Thread Reply:* @Eric ya State would be expected to behave the same as StateObject here since the motivation is to limit memory growth by avoiding preserving state for an unbounded number of (offscreen) views

2022-06-08 22:46:39

2022-06-08 22:53:04

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:41:11

@Lars asked > Is there a way to have an onChange(of:perform:) Modifier but only call the closure, when the state was changed by the user and not programmatically?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:41:22

*Thread Reply:* onChange executes its closure whenever the value change (that‚Äôs why we require the value to be Equatable). So onChange only know about comparing the value that your are providing.

If you want to make that distinction you probably should model that difference in your state.

Ilter
2022-06-08 22:44:56

*Thread Reply:* We have the same use case and we‚Äôre hooking into the action closure of a button separately for example.

Ilter
2022-06-08 22:45:56

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôd love to have a way similar to .valueChanged events from UIKit though. üòÖ

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:42:40

@Sergio Andres asked > There has been a lot of controversy regarding the ObservedObject(wrappedValue: ) initializer. Is it safe (and encouraged) to use it, or do we have an alternative for it this year?

üëç Lowell, Sebastian
Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:42:48

*Thread Reply:* This initializer is fine to use! In fact, the ObservedObject(wrappedValue:) initializer is invoked every time you construct an ObservedObject , even if you don‚Äôt explicitly write it yourself. When you write: @ObservedObject var myObservedObject = myModel, The Swift compiler converts that standard property wrapper syntax to a call that looks something like: var _myObservedObject = ObservedObject(wrappedValue: myModel).

The controversy I think you‚Äôre referring to is using that initializer explicitly in the initializer for one of your views. Typically, we see people doing this to allow observed objects to be instantiated with specific information. That is also something which we think is fine to do. We recognize that the ergonomics of that case is not ideal (since you have to access the de-sugared property wrapped (in the example I gave, _myObservedObject), but it‚Äôs not at all harmful.

üëç Eduardo, Thibaut, Sergio Andres
Lowell
2022-06-08 22:43:18

*Thread Reply:* What about the State initializer?

Tom
2022-06-08 22:45:38

*Thread Reply:* I think the confusion comes from this comment: /// Don't call this initializer directly. Instead, declare a property /// with the ``State`` attribute, and provide an initial value:

üëç Lowell, Sergio Andres, Chang, Jeremy
Muthuveerappan
2022-06-08 22:45:59

*Thread Reply:* I think ObservedObject also has a the initialiser init(initialValue:) is that preferred? The documentation doesn't mention any warning on this initialiser

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:47:17

*Thread Reply:* The state initializer worries me a bit more. Not because it‚Äôs dangerous ‚Äî it‚Äôs totally fine to use it yourself (as I mentioned, the normal syntax is just sugar for the fully spelled out case) ‚Äî but because I can‚Äôt think of as many cases where you need that syntax for @State that aren‚Äôt dangerous.

Remember that @State is initialized once per lifetime of the whole view, not once per time a view‚Äôs initializer is called The views representation will be recreated on demand. That means that if you‚Äôre re-initializing the state every time the views init is called, you‚Äôre going to be clobbering your own state.

‚úÖ Ilter, Tom
‚ù§Ô∏è Ilter
Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:48:57

*Thread Reply:* So that‚Äôs fine to do, but make sure that you‚Äôre only using it to set the initial value of a state, and that you‚Äôre not resetting your state depending on some initializer value.

Ilter
2022-06-08 22:49:02

*Thread Reply:* @Sam L (Apple) I believe same applies for @Binding and co. too?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:49:05

*Thread Reply:* Yup!

Ilter
2022-06-08 22:49:42

*Thread Reply:* But for @Binding is it still harmful? Because source of truth is already on a parent view or somewhere up there?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:50:26

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, binding is also one of the cases that would sound alarm bells for me ‚ö†Ô∏è

Ilter
2022-06-08 22:51:01

*Thread Reply:* Yeah fair, I‚Äôd still be cautious instead of making assumptions. Very nice tip though, thank you! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:52:24

*Thread Reply:* As a final note: regarding the ‚Äúdon‚Äôt call this initializer directly,‚Äù that‚Äôs mostly because as I mentioned, the cases where you ‚Äúneed‚Äù the underlying initializer (for @State and @Binding especially) are few and far between. Most of the time, you‚Äôd want to be using the standard property wrapper syntax, so we want to make sure people reading the docs look there first.

Muthuveerappan
2022-06-08 22:53:27

*Thread Reply:* Is the concern because State variable's lifetime is outside the view's lifetime and initialising the State variable in the view's initialiser would keep creating a new State every time the view get's created?

Lowell
2022-06-08 22:53:32

*Thread Reply:* A recent use case where i would have used it was to pass in a value to a structs initializer, where that struct is also @State

Tom
2022-06-08 22:56:31

*Thread Reply:* Interesting. The place I was using it was that I had a @FetchRequest that was based on a relationship to another object, so I was passing the object into init and then creating the fetch request based on it but was keeping that object as State.

Maybe I don't really need it to be State.

Tom
2022-06-08 22:57:00

*Thread Reply:* But maybe I shouldn't be creating the FetchRequest wrapper that way either?

Axel
2022-06-08 23:12:07

*Thread Reply:* @Tom I noticed in this case that the FetchRequest is init everytime the View is init. It does not behave like a State or StateObject where the property is tied to the lifetime of the View. So if I use a predicate or sortDescriptors updated by my subview, any update in the super view will reset the predicate/sortDescriptor. So these should be higher in the hierarchy, or based on a State.

Malcolm
2022-06-08 23:15:24

*Thread Reply:* @Axel @Tom same thing here FB9956812. The FetchRequest struct mistakenly contains a var object that it inits every time which breaks SwiftUI's View identity matching so body is called every time. Really hope it is fixed in this beta cycle.

Malcolm
2022-06-08 23:15:58

*Thread Reply:* @Tom you can init a FetchRequest with params like this:

private var fetchRequest: FetchRequest&lt;Appointment&gt; private var appointments: FetchedResults&lt;Appointment&gt; { fetchRequest.wrappedValue }

`init(date: Date, userID: String) {`
  `fetchRequest = FetchRequest(fetchRequest: Appointment.sortedFetchRequest(userId: userId, date: date))`
`}`
Malcolm
2022-06-08 23:16:27

*Thread Reply:* That wrappedValue trick is taken from the SectionedFetchRequest header comments.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:43:39

@Eduardo asked > Is using @EnvironmentObject for dependency injection of entities not directly related to the view state, like a Service (to fetch values from network) or a telemetry logger, considered bad practice? > Thinking on a MVVM architecture context.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:45:35

*Thread Reply:* I wouldn't consider it a bad practice

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:46:19

*Thread Reply:* Be mindful when using plain @Environment, that if you're passing a struct, any change in value will invalidate any views reading that value from the environment

üëç Eduardo
Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:47:30

*Thread Reply:* But if you're using @EnvironmentObject with a class that's effectively immutable that shouldn't be a problem

üëç Eduardo, Klayton

2022-06-08 22:53:13

Muthuveerappan
2022-06-08 23:04:12

Malcolm
2022-06-08 23:19:26

*Thread Reply:* @Ilter it's best to learn the View struct, it is actually a view model so you don't need another view model object in SwiftUI. If you do use them you'll just get the bugs typical of objects that SwiftUI has been designed to eliminate by its use of value type structs.

Ilter
2022-06-08 23:21:25

*Thread Reply:* For simple use cases, yes, I agree. I do exactly this in my own app, but it doesn‚Äôt scale in a larger team working on a complex project. Especially as we‚Äôre adopting SwiftUI incrementally.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:44:08

@Duncan asked > I have a UIKit app on iOS. I am at the point of needing to decide‚Äîdo I ship it for macOS with Catalyst, or given I‚Äôm doing a major redesign anyway, do I migrate it to be a SwiftUI app. > > I am wondering‚Äîare any of the features/capabilities that I would have in a Catalyst app to make the app more "Mac like" that are not available on macOS using a native SwiftUI app? e.g., the "Bring your iOS app to the Mac" session showed the ability in Catalyst to enable/disable the traffic light buttons when they were not appropriate for that window. Is this kind of control also available in SwiftUI on macOS?

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:47:29

*Thread Reply:* Hi - thanks for the question! With regards to your last part around the window controls (traffic lights) - SwiftUI will enable/disable these depending on the content of the scene. So, for example, a content view with a fixed size, will have the zoom and fullscreen button disabled. I'd also like to point out that on macOS Ventura, SwiftUI App lifecycle windows will be fully flexible by default (they can be resized to the maximum allowed by the screen). This can be opted out with a new Scene modifier - windowResizability. ie: WindowGroup { } .windowResizability(.contentSize)

üëç:skin_tone_3: Duncan
Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:48:18

*Thread Reply:* Enabling/disabling of full screen behavior is also related to the maximum size of the window's contents and how that relates to the screen size of the device

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:50:58

*Thread Reply:* If there are other aspects that you would like to customize here, a feedback would be appreciated as well.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:44:45

@Adam asked > What is the best way to debug issues with the Live Preview when an error isn't thrown / the build doesn't actually fail and the "Diagnostic" button isn't available? Chris J (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:45:16

*Thread Reply:* In the new Xcode the diagnostic button is now always available in Xcode's menu Editor > Canvas > Diagnostics, so you can access them even when the canvas doesn't show an error banner.

Hard to say without the diagnostics (and potentially your project) what the root cause is, but from the symptoms it sounds like maybe your project has a script phase that modifies some of the source as part of the build? If you file a feedback with the diagnostic we might be able to help narrow down where things are going wrong.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:50:39

@Jason asked > Is there a recommended best practice for managing StateObjects/ObservableObjects in a primary-detail type setup? I've been commonly using StateObject(wrappedValue:) to inject a stateobject into a detail view, but of course because wrappedValue is an autoclosure it doesn't get updates to the data value that may occur from the primary view. Passing the entire primary StateObject to the detail view can expose more data to the detail view than necessary. And creating and managing an ObservableObject owned by the primary StateObject can be boilerplatey and messy to manage. Any approaches I've overlooked, or tips on how to approach those tradeoffs?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:52:20

*Thread Reply:* My intuition is that for a primary-detail setup, you would want the detail using @ObservedObject (or even @Binding) instead of @StateObject.

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:53:56

*Thread Reply:* @State and @StateObject are defining a source of truth and lifetime for the state/model.

You want the lifetime of the state/model to live on beyond changing the selection in the primary.

@ObservedObject will listen to changed in the model object and update the view without establishing a new source of truth.

üëç Malcolm
Jan
2022-06-08 22:56:47

*Thread Reply:* > I agree with @Kyle M (Apple) and would like to add that I read somewhere that using (wrappedValue:) of State/StateObject in this way is discouraged. I will try to find the source. > For your use case, I would use @StateObject in root, then @ObservedObject in detail, or @Binding in detail if you only want to expose something specific

Jason
2022-06-08 22:57:51

*Thread Reply:* Is the recommendation to inject the entire root StateObject into the detail as an ObservableObject, or for the root StateObject to create and maintain an ObservableObject which has the subset of relevant data, and inject that into the detail view?

Jan
2022-06-08 22:59:09

*Thread Reply:* the latter

Jan
2022-06-08 22:59:53

*Thread Reply:* Content view <- State Object, holds the truth Detail view <- ObservedObject/Binding, refers to the truth

‚úÖ Jason
üôå Jason
Jason
2022-06-08 23:00:36

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. That was my instinct too... I just don't want to manage it. üòõ But it's probably a good choice.

Jan
2022-06-08 23:02:35

*Thread Reply:* If you wanna take the pro route üòé you will rely on protocols, and inject instances as needed using a custom property wrapper. The instances will be stored using a custom class (or save yourself trouble and use something like Resolver)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:50:43

@Christopher asked > With NavigationPath, I've already felt the need to pass it down to child views as a @Binding or @EnvironmentObject so that they can influence the stack programatically. Is that a reasonable approach or am I overlooking something?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:51:15

*Thread Reply:* Passing the binding or passing a navigation model as an environment object are both reasonable approaches with the API we have available today.

I hope we can make this more ergonomic. I‚Äôd love a Feedback with your use case!

üëç Christopher
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:52:11

*Thread Reply:* I personally like the navigation model approach, since I can easily do other work when the navigation state changes without putting that code in my Views.

üëÄ Thomas
üëç Christopher
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:52:22

*Thread Reply:* But either approach works fine.

Christopher
2022-06-08 22:53:00

*Thread Reply:* So, a ViewModel (probably observableobject) that dictates navigation?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:53:49

*Thread Reply:* Yeah. That works for the way I think about navigation.

:gratitude_thank_you: Christopher, Moritz
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:57:23

@Thomas asked > Could a WindowGroup value that has no stored dependencies be recreated along the lifecycle of an app?

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:57:51

*Thread Reply:* Hi - would you be able to provide some more detail here? I'd like to make sure I understand your question fully.

Thomas
2022-06-08 23:01:47

*Thread Reply:* If some value is stored not in a @State in the WindowGroup, for example, let uuid = UUID(). Will it stay the same in this specific case for the lifetime of the app. This is of course a bad practice, but I've seen it quite some time on the internet, and I would like to know if in this specific case, the value could be recreated or not as the app runs. This is more a theoretical question to try to get a better grasp around this specific value lifecycle.

Thomas
2022-06-08 23:03:04

*Thread Reply:* In other words, are WindowGroup susceptible of being recreated even if they have no stored dependencies, no @State, etc.

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:04:56

*Thread Reply:* I see. I think for this, I would likely recommend storing this in an app-level model, and providing that value to the WindowGroup

Thomas
2022-06-08 23:06:09

*Thread Reply:* But are there (private) system events that can recreate the WindowGroup?

Thomas
2022-06-08 23:07:07

*Thread Reply:* Mostly a theoretical question. I would always store something safely elsewhere, but I don't know if in this specific case, this is overzealous.

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:09:01

*Thread Reply:* I don't think it's being overzealous, if that is what you are concerned about.

Thomas
2022-06-08 23:22:13

*Thread Reply:* Thanks!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:58:57

@James Michael asked > Is it possible to use @State, et. al from within a custom Layout? Or is there a different way we should parameterize our layouts? I noticed that the protocol doesn't inherit from View, so I wasn't sure if using the property wrappers would work.

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:59:31

*Thread Reply:* You can add input parameters to your layout, and you can attach values to particular views using the LayoutValueKey protocol. To store data between calls into your layout, you can use the cache, but that‚Äôs only to avoid repeated calculations, and you should be prepared for the cache to go away at any time.

James Michael
2022-06-08 23:01:10

*Thread Reply:* Okay, so anything stateful should live in the parent view (and be passed as init args) or in a child view (and be read through a LayoutValueKey) ?

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:01:21

*Thread Reply:* Yes

James Michael
2022-06-08 23:01:30

*Thread Reply:* Makes sense, thanks!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:59:19

@Ilter asked > Is there a newer way to debug a view while it's in preview?

Chris J (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:59:37

*Thread Reply:* Best way to debug a preview now would be to use Xcode's menu item Debug > Attach to Process (or the Process by Pid or Name) and select/use the name of your app. Then update a string literal in that view and it should cause the View's body to get called and hit any breakpoints you've got in that code.

Hope that helps!

‚ÄºÔ∏è Tom, Max, Moritz, Sara F (Apple), Christopher, Patrice, Xuesi
üò≤ Enrico
Tom
2022-06-08 23:00:28

*Thread Reply:* OMG! That is amazing.

Ilter
2022-06-08 23:00:48

*Thread Reply:* Awesome thanks!

2022-06-08 22:59:20

@Andrew asked > I would like to migrate my (very complex) iMessage app extension to SwiftUI. How do I deal with the MSMessagesAppViewController? Do I need to use some mix of UIHostingController and UIViewRepresentable?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:59:44

*Thread Reply:* You should use the UIHostingController as a child of the MSMessagesAppViewController

‚úÖ Andrew
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:00:12

@Thomas asked > When implementing path(in: CGRect) of a Shape, are dynamic Property Wrappers assumed offer the correct values, or is this only valid for bodies?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:00:33

*Thread Reply:* Shapes don‚Äôt have the same data flow primitives as views do, so things like state, environment, etc. won‚Äôt work, but don‚Äôt despair! You can still get the results that I think you might want. Since you‚Äôll eventually be showing your shapes somewhere in a SwiftUI View, you can hoist your data flow up to the SwiftUI View level, then pass down that information about state, environment, etc. down to the shapes.

üëç Thomas
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:00:22

@Ryan asked > What is the best way to make a TextField wrap? I noticed some new API regarding lineLimits and axes, and wondering if those provide some functionality in this area.

Harry L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:01:44

*Thread Reply:* TextFields can be initialized with a new axis parameter. If you provide a .vertical axis, then platforms like iOS and macOS will wrap the text of the text field in a scrollable container instead of letting the text expand horizontally.

See one of its inits here: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/textfield/init(_:text:axis:)-7n1bm

üëè Ryan, Ryan, Christopher
üôè Thomas, Christopher
Ryan
2022-06-08 23:02:06

*Thread Reply:* Awesome, thanks!

Harry L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:03:37

*Thread Reply:* These text fields will also respect the line limit modifier. So specifying a lineLimit(3) will let the text field grow vertically up to 3 lines and then it will stop growing and scroll instead.

‚úÖ Ryan
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:00:25

@Petar asked > As we get more and more familiar with SwiftUI we use GeometryReader less and less, but what are some tells that there's no way around it?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:01:28

*Thread Reply:* If you want a visual effect like corner radius, opacity, or color to depend on your geometry, GeometryReader is the way to bridge between these two worlds

üôè Petar
Ben
2022-06-08 23:02:06

*Thread Reply:* I particularly use GeometryReader a ton to contextualize Gestures (e.g. to see whether the user has dragged all the way to the left or right of a control). Is there a different way?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:03:57

*Thread Reply:* Layout gives you a superior tool for encapsulating layout logic for re-use. And while using GeometryReader you can position children, the GeometryReader can't reflect back any custom sizing behavior.

This is one of the reasons it can become unwieldy when used in complex layouts‚Äîbecause the GeometryReader becomes fully flexible.

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:05:00

*Thread Reply:* Ben, would the new SpatialTapGesture help? https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/spatialtapgesture

üòØ Adrian
üëÄ Ben
Adrian
2022-06-08 23:07:12

*Thread Reply:* What is the difference between SpatialTapGesture and TapGesture? ü§î

2022-06-08 23:09:02

*Thread Reply:* @Paul L (Apple) Is it possible to understand the extent of the view from SpatialTapGesture? My main use case is determining where the touch is within a view (ie knowing that a touch is 10% left and 30% from the top)

Ben
2022-06-08 23:12:02

*Thread Reply:* ‚Ä¶I'm also squinting at SpatialTapGesture and seeing whether I could hack "true" pinch to zoom (with location) using this new API ü§î

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:04:10

@Petar asked > Would you recommend to use @State/@ObservedObject for any cases where where we don't expect the object to mutate?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:05:09

*Thread Reply:* If the values you‚Äôre represented are never going to change, there‚Äôs no need to use @State or @ObservedObject. I highly recommend just making and using a standard struct.

üôè Petar
Ilter
2022-06-08 23:06:01

*Thread Reply:* @Sam L (Apple) what about reference types in views? Would let suffice?

Petar
2022-06-08 23:08:16

*Thread Reply:* Should I ever be concerned that as the view gets thrown away and recreated my UISelectionFeedbackGenerator instance (for example) will be continuously re-created as well?

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:08:21

*Thread Reply:* Let would not suffice for reference types! A let binding for a reference type just says: ‚ÄúThis will always point to the same instance of the object‚Äù. It doesn‚Äôt guarantee that that instance is immutable. If you can guarantee that your reference type is completely immutable, then you should be fine, but that can be a hard thing to ensure, so be cautious (and I would highly recommend using structs where you can)

‚úÖ Ilter
:gratitude_thank_you: Ilter
Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:09:54

*Thread Reply:* Petar, I wouldn‚Äôt ever be concerned that your view gets thrown away and recreated. That‚Äôs by design. SwiftUI views aren‚Äôt linked to their actual UI representation, but rather are lightweight descriptions of views that can be recomputed quickly and easily. You should expect your views to be thrown away and recreated very frequently.

‚ù§Ô∏è Christopher
Petar
2022-06-08 23:14:30

*Thread Reply:* Thank you @Sam L (Apple), and just to hammer to point: Don‚Äôt worry not just that the views are getting recreated, but also what instances get recreated with them.

2022-06-08 23:04:47

Chris J (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:05:03

*Thread Reply:* No, unfortunately not. The preview is only interactive when viewing it in the Live mode, and all the other modes are static previews

Chris J (Apple)

*Thread Reply:* yes, use the Device Settings button to change the orientation to be landscape

üôå Shannon
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:05:56

@Edward asked > with the new any keyword, will we still need AnyView to type erase views, or can we declare a collection with any View now? will this also have the same performance implications of using type erased views?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:06:06

*Thread Reply:* Ideally you should not use AnyView and over the year ViewBuilder has improved enough that you should be able to eliminate most, if not all, its usage.

That said, yes you will still need to use AnyView because you need to actually instantiate that type, and not just use View as a type. any View is just defining an (existential container) box.

Edward
2022-06-08 23:23:33

*Thread Reply:* is it possible to use view builders as function params or property types without Generics?

we are using AnyView to present content. there are different types of content each represented by an enum with associated value. This forced us to use AnyView to have concrete types. What would be your suggestion to move away from AnyView in this use case? Thank you ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:31:30

*Thread Reply:* If you have finite number of views you are displaying described by an enum could you switch over that enum in body of a view? ViewBuilder does support switch statements

üëç Edward
≈Åukasz
2022-06-08 23:44:21

*Thread Reply:* I have similar use case. Sometimes I would like to not couple the view which other views it present, but instead use other Flow/Factory logic that shows whats needed depending on the business logic. It forces me to use AnyView . E.g. ```struct MainView: View { @ObservedObject var viewModel: MainViewModel var channelsViewFactory: (Int?) -> AnyView

var body: some View {
    Text("ABC")
    channelsViewFactory(viewModel.selectedId)
}

} ... extension AppDependencies: MainViewFactory { func makeMainView() -> MainView { return MainView( channelsViewFactory: { id in if loggedIn { self.makeChannelsView(for: id) } else { self.makeSignInView() } } } }```

Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:49:52

*Thread Reply:* It really depends on your use case. But most of the time, if you're in the situation where you think you need [AnyView] or [any View], what you should likely do is invert the view dependency flow and have [AnyDataModel or [any DataModel] instead, then create your views based on the type of data provided at runtime.

‚òùÔ∏è Harlan
üëç Edward
Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:51:32

*Thread Reply:* In ≈Åukasz case, you could introduce generics into MainView (e.g., MainView&lt;ChannelsView: View&gt;: View) and then create a container view above MainView to encapsulate the generic constraint(s).

Chris J (Apple)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:12:00

@Kyle asked > My app‚Äôs design uses kerning on most of its buttons, but I can‚Äôt put that inside of my ButtonStyle because kerning is only available on Text, not ButtonStyleConfiguration.Label. I have a feedback open suggesting passing kerning through the environment (FB10020695). > > In the meantime, do you have any suggestions on how to do this without using .kerning() separately on every button label nor making a custom button View?

Kyle M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:13:42

*Thread Reply:* The only other thing I can think of is to create a Button wrapper view that requires a Text be passed in as a parameter. Then attach kerning to the Text yourself and pass it to the underlying Button

Kyle
2022-06-08 23:18:36

*Thread Reply:* Haha, was hoping to avoid that so we didn‚Äôt need to handle other permutations like buttons with text and an icon, etc üôÇ

One other avenue I‚Äôve been exploring is a custom Text view that accepts kerning through an Environment value applied by the ButtonStyle, though that has led to needing to reimplement multiple inits from Text. Doesn‚Äôt feel too great, either üòì

Thanks!

Luke
2022-06-08 23:41:43

*Thread Reply:* @Kyle the approach I normally take here Is to create a reusable view specifically for the button label rather than an entire button view. This results in code that composes nicely. I still use button styles for styling buttons more generally.

Kyle
2022-06-08 23:47:33

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Luke, that‚Äôs sort of the direction I was headed with the ‚Äúcustom Text view‚Äù idea‚Äîthink like: Button(action: {}) { MyAppText("Hello World") } and then the ButtonStyle would set kerning in the environment for MyAppText to look at.

Still means our team needs to remember to use MyAppText instead of Text, but maybe that‚Äôll be easier to remember than peppering .kerning everywhere üòÑ

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:16:09

@Oluwatobi asked > How would one go about creating a Bubble Chart with Swift Charts?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:18:03

*Thread Reply:* You can use the symbolSize(by:) modifier (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/charts/chartcontent/symbolsize(by:)) to size the points by data.

To make the points look like bubbles, you can use .symbol(Circle().strokeBorder(lineWidth: 1)) so the symbols are drawn as stroked circles.

Here is an example: Chart(data) { PointMark( x: .value("Wing Length", $0.wingLength), y: .value("Wing Width", $0.wingWidth) ) .symbolSize(by: .value("Weight", $0.weight)) .symbol(Circle().strokeBorder(lineWidth: 1)) }

üòç An
üëç An
Oluwatobi
2022-06-08 23:55:55

*Thread Reply:* great, thanks

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:16:25

@Philipp asked > SwiftUI macOS: How can I control how the focus moves around the controls of my view when I press "tab"? Currently it jumps from top left to right, then down. But I have two columns in my window and would prefer it go down first on the left side and then again up to the right. > Is there some functionality to pre-define the order of the controls?

üíØ Maximilian
Cody B (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:18:18

*Thread Reply:* You can use View.focusSection() for this, which is newly available on macOS 13.0. Marking a view as a focus section causes the Tab loop to cycle through all of the section's focusable content as a group before moving on to the next thing in layout order. So, something like this should get you the sort of column-wise navigation you're after:

```struct ContentView: View { var body: some View { HStack { VStack { FocusableView() FocusableView() } .focusSection()

        VStack {
            FocusableView()
            FocusableView()
        }
        .focusSection()
    }
}

}```

üëç Christopher, Philipp
ü§© Dmitry
Philipp
2022-06-08 23:26:07

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, that's nice!

Cody B (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:27:53

*Thread Reply:* Also, a plug for my colleague Tanu's WWDC21 talk: Direct and reflect focus in SwiftUI

https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10023/

It goes over some tvOS use cases for View.focusSection(), and also describes how to work with focus programmatically using focus state bindings.

Apple Developer
Direct and reflect focus in SwiftUI - WWDC21 - Videos - Apple Developer
With device input ‚Äî as with all things in life ‚Äî where you put focus matters. Discover how you can move focus in your app with SwiftUI,...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10023/

I feel more motivated than ever to keep pushing for more great software, and to share as much of that energy that I got from the team with the rest of the development community.

ü•≥ Evelyn R (Apple)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:21:04

@Brian asked > With the new MenuBarExtra API on the Mac, if I want the menu item to be persistent after my app quits, do I need to do any extra work (e.g. adding a login item) or does the system automagically make sure it appears after reboot/logout?

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:23:56

*Thread Reply:* Hi - this is a great question. You can certainly use MenuBarExtra to create a standalone menu bar app, though you may want to look into the Info.plist changes noted in the documentation: > For apps that only show in the menu bar, a common behavior is for the app to not display its icon in either the Dock or the application switcher. To enable this behavior, set the LSUIElement flag in your app‚Äôs Info.plist file to true. If the menu bar app is used in conjunction with a main app, then you'll need to package it together (ie, the "helper app" model). Adding a login item sounds like the way to go if you want it to show at login regardless of the user's preference for restoring state.

Jeff R (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:24:55

*Thread Reply:* We'd also certainly welcome any feedbacks for enhancement requests in this area as well.

Brian
2022-06-08 23:26:38

*Thread Reply:* Got it, that combined with the new login item APIs this year should make this sort of thing a lot easier. Thanks!

üôè Jeff R (Apple)
Malcolm
2022-06-08 23:32:50

*Thread Reply:* @Jeff R (Apple) Please make MenuBarExtra available in Catalyst so we can use it with HomeKit which is Catalyst only on Mac at present.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:26:37

@Lior asked > Is there any specific style guide for SwiftUI ? > > There are some cases in SwiftUI that I'm not sure what's the best. > f.e. > var body: some View { > myAmazingView > } > > (More readable) > > or > > var body: some View { my AmazingView } > > (A one-liner!)

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:27:02

*Thread Reply:* We don‚Äôt have any specific style guide! Use whatever you and your team think feels best. Personally, I‚Äôm never opposed to writing one liners on one line in Swift though üôÇ The language is so beautifully concise, so I like to embrace that.

üëç Lior, Ron
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:29:59

@Christopher asked > If your app is always behind an authentication session what is a good approach for blocking the app's content when authentication is required? In UIKit apps it was common to display a separate UIWindow atop your app's main window. Is this still a good way of handling it in a SwiftUI app?

üëÄ Thomas
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:30:10

*Thread Reply:* Interesting question!

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:31:22

*Thread Reply:* Without knowing the details of your app, my inclination would be to try the RedactionReasons API.

üß† Andrew
Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:32:35

*Thread Reply:* You can use the .redacted modifier to set a redaction reason. SwiftUI controls will automatically react to that, hiding sensitive data. You can also read the reason from the environment to redact in custom controls.

Andrew
2022-06-08 23:32:37

*Thread Reply:* Not the most elegant, but I‚Äôve done something like this if let _ = auth.sessionToken { ContentView() } else { AuthView() }

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:34:23

*Thread Reply:* You could also use an overlay modifier at the root of your hierarchy to present a view over the whole app, then adjust that view‚Äôs opacity based on the log in state.

ü§î Thomas
Christopher
2022-06-08 23:35:14

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, it's not a cookie cutter kind of problem but curious about other ideas

Ilter
2022-06-08 23:37:02

*Thread Reply:* Personally, I‚Äôd prefer swapping rootViewController of the app‚Äôs window in a UIKit environment. I think the closest approach in SwiftUI would be as Andrew shared above. Not sure if this would cover the need in question though.

üëç Christopher
Thomas
2022-06-08 23:38:36

*Thread Reply:* This is my approach currently, but it‚Äôs got some drawbacks... I‚Äôm interested to know how others are doing. WindowGroup { switch userSessionManager.isLoggedIn { case true: TabViewScreen() // .viewModifiers //(environmentObjects, etc.) case false: LoginScreen() } }

Christopher
2022-06-08 23:41:58

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, the main drawback of conditionally showing different content is you kind of destroy the user's current context as you show the LoginScreen() which is why I like the window approach

Thomas
2022-06-08 23:47:39

*Thread Reply:* I tried using .fullScreenCover instead to fix that. But that does not guarantee that your sensitive data will always be covered up when the user is logged out mid-session. e.g. when another sheet or fullScreenCover from a subview is already shown, and even when it is dismissed later. .objectWillChange isn‚Äôt called again and the login screen does not pop back up.

Thomas
2022-06-08 23:49:57

*Thread Reply:* This is actually still a problem with the above approach. So sadly I tend to avoid using sheets and fullScreenCovers for that reason.

üëç Christopher
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:30:12

@Tim asked > is it recommended to use switch-case views for e.g. showing different view types in a list or grid instead of using specific types via generics etc.?. are there any better ways? > like: > List(items) { item &gt; switch item.type { &gt; case ...: &gt; SomeView(item) &gt; case : ... &gt; } &gt; }

Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:33:38

*Thread Reply:* When you use a switch within a @ViewBuilder closure, you are in fact using the power of generics üòâ, but in most common cases you hopefully don‚Äôt have to think about that overtly.

In general, using switch in view builders is a great tool! The best approach really case-by-case though, just as when deciding to use a switch versus other control flow in regular imperative code.

‚úÖ Gary
Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:34:33

*Thread Reply:* Are there any specific alternatives to a switch you were considering?

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:39:40

@Ilter asked > Does branching in a views body (via if-else or switch) cause the creation of each branch's views?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:39:54

*Thread Reply:* It only creates the views for the branch of the if/switch that‚Äôs actually taken.

üëç Ilter
‚ù§Ô∏è Ilter, Gernot
Christian
2022-06-08 23:40:42
