SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:41:44

@Tyson asked > What is the best way to pass down data managers, specifically a media player to subviews?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:41:51

*Thread Reply:* You can pass them just as argument to your subview initializer. If you have multiple subviews or the subview that needs to use that data manager is further down the hierarchy you could use the Environment to pass is down

Tyson
2022-06-08 23:43:03

*Thread Reply:* Great. Is there an example of this somewhere?

Luca B (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:46:45

*Thread Reply:* The documentation for EnvironmentKey has code example for it https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/environmentkey

Tyson
2022-06-08 23:47:16

*Thread Reply:* Wonderful, thank you!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:42:46

@Rob asked > Is it a known problem that using a custom Layout with multiple subviews doesn't compile? For example, this minor change to the CustomLayoutSample project, adding a second subview to the use of MyEqualWidthHStack, won't compile: > > struct ButtonStack: View { > var body: some View { > ViewThatFits { // Choose the first view that fits. > MyEqualWidthHStack { // Arrange horizontally if it fits... > Buttons() > Text("hello") > } > MyEqualWidthVStack { // ...or vertically, otherwise. > Buttons() > } > } > } > } > > Or am I just doing it wrong? > > FB10113527

Paul L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:43:23

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a known issue. See the iOS and iPadOS release notes here: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/ios-ipados-release-notes/ios-ipados-16-release-notes

You can search for ‚Äúcustom Layout‚Äù

üëç Rob
üôå Jordan
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:46:10

@Yannik asked > How can I change the (text) color of the scales at the sides in a Swift Charts?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:48:12

*Thread Reply:* You can change the color of the axis labels with the .chart{X/Y}Axis modifier, where you can configure the foregroundStyle of AxisValueLabel . Here is an example changing the label color for the Y axis: .chartYAxis { AxisMarks { _ in AxisGridLine() AxisTick() AxisValueLabel().foregroundStyle(Color.red) } } You can change the color of the grid line and tick in a similar way too.

Yannik
2022-06-09 00:05:47

*Thread Reply:* Could it be that this currently doesn't work in the developer beta? Because I just tried the following code and it applied the colors on the grid line and tick, but not on the label next to the tick. ```.chartYAxis { AxisMarks { _ in AxisGridLine() .foregroundStyle(.yellow)

                AxisTick()
                .foregroundStyle(.blue)

                AxisValueLabel()
                .foregroundStyle(.red)
            }
        }```
Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:54:01

*Thread Reply:* Yes, looks like this is a bug in the beta. Feel free to file a bug via Feedback Assistant.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:51:15

@Ilter asked > As we are incrementally adopting SwiftUI in a UIKit app, are there guidelines for replacing the patterns that we are used to in a UIKit app, like delegate pattern, notifications, target-actions etc? Some of these are obvious but I kind of feel I'm doing something wrong whenever I pass a closure into a view to get a feedback to replicate delegate pattern for example. üòÖ

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:51:57

*Thread Reply:* Delegates do a lot of different things in UIKit, and so the way that they should be translated into SwiftUI can vary heavily depending on what they‚Äôre being used for in UIKit. In some situations they‚Äôll become closures that you pass around, in others, a Binding or State, sometimes a onChange(of:), etc. UIKit and SwiftUI have two very different programming models, so often times, concepts don‚Äôt map over in a one-to-one way.

I‚Äôd highly recommend you book a lab appointment so we can chat more about what specific case you‚Äôre trying to translate, and where your pain-points are there üôÇ

üëÄ Ilter
‚ù§Ô∏è Ilter, Muthuveerappan
Ilter
2022-06-08 23:54:32

*Thread Reply:* Awesome, will definitely do that. Can you please touch on using Combine for such feedback mechanisms? I also explored passing a subject into a view to observe a feedback but that also felt a bit wrong.

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:54:15

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:58:30

@Cristian-Mihai asked > How can I add use an SVG in my SwiftUI app?

Matt R (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:00:05

*Thread Reply:* You can add an SVG in the asset catalog and it can be rendered via a named Image.

Checking ‚Äúpreserve vector content‚Äù (or similar) in the asset item preferences will render it from vectors instead of raster.

:gratitude_thank_you: Cristian-Mihai
üëç Cristian-Mihai
Jan
2022-06-09 00:00:25

*Thread Reply:* Drag SVG to Assets. In Inspector, check "Preserve vector data", and set scale to "single scale"

Alexey
2022-06-09 00:01:07

*Thread Reply:* Is there any way to load SVG image from file system?

Jan
2022-06-09 00:02:03

*Thread Reply:* Also, an important tip that should be more known: SVG foreground color can be changed dynamically! So you don't need different color versions of your SVG image if you want to change color while your app is running

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:58:30

@Lukas asked > I noticed that when a subview uses a binding to published variable from an ObservableObject, the subview's body will re-execute any time any of the other published variables in the ObservableObject are modified. Even if this modified variable isn't used by the subview at all. Is this a bug or a performance concern?

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:58:55

*Thread Reply:* The subview updates based on the objectWillChange publisher, which is a composite of all the published properties. This is by design, but can require fine tuning of models.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:59:32

*Thread Reply:* Different apps can handle this different ways, so this might be an excellent question for a lab.

Curt C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:00:06

*Thread Reply:* Or even a Developer Technical Support ticket!

Lukas
2022-06-09 00:00:22

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

Christian
2022-06-09 00:01:10

*Thread Reply:* And views are incredibly cheap in SwiftUI! Don‚Äôt hesitate to break them up into smaller pieces.

And generally avoid side effects in your view‚Äôs initializer. Generally, IMO, I wouldn‚Äôt expect performance concerns from the body being repeatedly invoked.

Malcolm
2022-06-09 00:07:51

*Thread Reply:* Yeh pass properties of the object into subviews and then only the views that were given different values should have their body called. However if a view has a FetchRequest its body is called every time because of a long term bug!

Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:01:14

@Ben asked: > I‚Äôm seeing much choppier performance in SwiftUI with iOS 16 Beta 1 vs iOS 15‚Äîshould I troubleshoot my specific view hierarchy, or do you anticipate the framework becoming more optimized in later betas?

‚úÖ James
Sam L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:04:36

*Thread Reply:* We plan to improve things over the betas, but letting us know about problems you‚Äôre seeing (performance or behaviors) helps us know about and resolve them sooner, so please file feedbacks for any regressions you are seeing! Specific, reproducible performance regressions make especially good feedback reports üôÇ

‚ù§Ô∏è Ben, Patrice
Ben
2022-06-09 00:05:10

*Thread Reply:* Perfect, I'll do that‚Äîthank you @Sam L (Apple)!

*Thread Reply:* My asking my dad to show me a little javascript: alert() and prompt(); That‚Äôs pretty much all he knew.

‚ù§Ô∏è Jakub, Sara F (Apple), Paris P (Apple)
Paris P (Apple)
2022-06-09 03:45:41

*Thread Reply:* I had a logic/math professor in college that told me to try programming (I was a graphic designer and studying visual communication/marketing). My goal was to be a designer at Apple.

I was inspired by how he taught the same concepts to different groups in the class so they'd understand it with the right context. Nearly everyone passed his classes and understood the content.

5 years later, I was a full-time iOS engineer writing blog posts for self-taught programmers. Now, teaching best practices is my full-time job on all Apple platforms... at Apple. ‚ù§Ô∏è I still think of him a lot.

‚ù§Ô∏è Taylor K (Apple), Ron, Cody B (Apple), Marshall E (Apple), Sara F (Apple), Anne H (Apple), Curt C (Apple), Jake S (Apple), Lori H (Apple), Lee, Dan, Tristan

‚ù§Ô∏è Evelyn R (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:07:56

@Amy asked > I currently have a large data set (over 10k datapoints) that I'm working with. Are there any tips on how to improve the graph performance when working with creating line graphs from data sets of that size or larger? > > Context is cycling related data in a macOS app that is presenting 6 or more in a LazyVGrid.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:11:39

*Thread Reply:* We recommend simplifying the data before rendering it. For your example, you could simplify the line or summarize the data points in small intervals (let‚Äôs say you have data for a year, you summarize the data for a day). The added advantage is that you can summarize using mean, min and max and show the full range within the small interval.

Joseph
2022-06-09 20:16:41

*Thread Reply:* Sorry if non-Apple people aren't supposed to comment on this, but an Apple resource I found helpful with this kind of thing is using antialiasing filters to resample the data. https://developer.apple.com/documentation/accelerate/resampling_a_signal_with_decimation

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:31:31

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for the pointer @Joseph.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:32:43

*Thread Reply:* Another useful resource are the number and date bins we released this year: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/charts/datebins and https://developer.apple.com/documentation/charts/numberbins.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:09:47

@David asked > Is there a way to get AreaMark to work with .chartYScale(domain: .automatic(includesZero: false))? As soon as I add an AreaMark it seems to always include 0 in the scale.

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:14:24

*Thread Reply:* You could try setting yStart and yEnd for the area, here is an example: Chart(data) { AreaMark( x: .value("Date", $0.date), yStart: .value("Start Price", 100), yEnd: .value("Price", $0.price) ) } .chartYScale(domain: .automatic(includesZero: false)) The automatic option will use nicely rounded numbers. If that's not working for you, you can also set the domain directly like domain: 100 ... 1000

David
2022-06-09 20:27:39

*Thread Reply:* ü§î the first suggestion doesn‚Äôt quit work because there is some padding added to the y range. I‚Äôll give a specific range a try next.

Screen Shot 2022-06-09 at 11.26.59 AM.png
David
2022-06-09 20:33:23

*Thread Reply:* Just setting a range doesn‚Äôt quit work either‚Ä¶ I guess I would need to do both?

Screen Shot 2022-06-09 at 11.33.03 AM.png
Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:42:01

*Thread Reply:* Umm, could you try turning off roundLowerBound in axis marks? Full code would be like this: Chart(data) { AreaMark( x: .value("Date", $0.date), yStart: .value("Start Price", 100), yEnd: .value("Price", $0.price) ) } .chartYScale(domain: .automatic(includesZero: false)) .chartXAxis { AxisMarks(values: .automatic(roundLowerBound: false)) }

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:43:02

*Thread Reply:* roundLowerBound tries to add a round number below the data range, that might be why we are seeing a 40,000 value below the area like in your first screenshot.

David
2022-06-09 20:45:06

*Thread Reply:* That works

üôå Donghao R (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:12:05

@Steven asked > Can Swift Charts be adapted for non-discrete data, like curves, etc today?

‚ûï David, Lexline, Kent
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:13:19

*Thread Reply:* You can render curves by sampling data points along the function and then rendering that. You can add interpolation to make the line look smooth. Swift Charts cannot directly render functions.

üëç David
Mayra M
2022-06-09 20:17:09

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Dominik M for clarifying the point of functions and Swift Charts.

Steven
2022-06-09 20:18:19

*Thread Reply:* @Dominik M (Apple) I was wondering if there were some kind of closure-based API to encapsulate the function, with parameters like range and increment

Steven
2022-06-09 20:42:23

*Thread Reply:* Examples

empty.jpg
Xray.jpg
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:46:15

*Thread Reply:* There is not but you could sample a few points and then render the line.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:13:41

@Artyom asked > Is there any sample code or documentation on how to display vector fields with Swift Charts?üôÉ

ü§© Juan
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:14:30

*Thread Reply:* Like this?

Screen Shot 2022-06-09 at 2.14.23 PM.png
Artyom
2022-06-09 20:14:46

*Thread Reply:* Yep

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:15:22

*Thread Reply:* This screenshot is from the Hello Swift Charts talk. Let me find the code for it.

üôá Artyom, Mayra M
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:19:39

*Thread Reply:* You can use a custom symbol (Arrow ). ``` Chart(data, id: .x) { PointMark(x: .value("x", $0.x), y: .value("y", $0.y)) .symbol(Arrow(angle: CGFloat(angle)) .foregroundStyle(by: .value("angle", angle)) .opacity(0.7) }

...

struct Arrow: ChartSymbolShape {
    let angle: CGFloat
    let size: CGFloat

    func path(in rect: CGRect) -&gt; Path {
        let w = rect.width ** size ** 0.05 + 0.6
        var path = Path()
        path.move(to: CGPoint(x: 0, y: 1))
        path.addLine(to: CGPoint(x: -0.2, y: -0.5))
        path.addLine(to: CGPoint(x: 0.2, y: -0.5))
        path.closeSubpath()
        return path.applying(.init(rotationAngle: angle))
            .applying(.init(scaleX: w, y: w))
            .applying(.init(translationX: rect.midX, y: rect.midY))
    }

    var perceptualUnitRect: CGRect {
        return CGRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 1, height: 1)
    }
}```
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:19:59

*Thread Reply:* This is not the complete code but should give you enough to make the example.

Artyom
2022-06-09 20:20:57

*Thread Reply:* Nice! That‚Äôs the thing I was looking for, thank you!

Artyom
2022-06-09 22:12:33

*Thread Reply:* Alright, I‚Äôm getting closer üòÑ What‚Äôs left is to figure out what the format was used for data in the sample and where angle came from ü§î

Screenshot 2022-06-09 at 23.10.14.png
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:35:39

*Thread Reply:* Very cool.

:gratitude_thank_you: Artyom
Artyom
2022-06-09 22:45:02

*Thread Reply:* And here we go

Screenshot 2022-06-09 at 23.44.02.png
Artyom
2022-06-09 22:47:56

*Thread Reply:* It is quite delightful to use this framework and the performance is great. Many thanks to the team üôè

Though, documentation seems to be out of sync with reality a bit. For example, this snippet from PointMark does not compile. I‚Äôm assuming that the functionality with KeyPaths is not in the first beta yet since I recall similar syntax from the sessions

Screenshot 2022-06-09 at 23.44.56.png
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:14:22

@Steven asked > How are large datasets handled, is there automatic sampling or some kind of recommended limit?

üëÄ Alexey, Christopher
Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:16:07

*Thread Reply:* There is no automatic sampling in Swift Charts. I would expect the "preferred" sampling method to vary on a case-by-case basis. I think the best approach is to see what works for you and then sample in a manner that is honest to your data as you run into performance issues. We're always looking to improve the performance of the framework! File feedback if you run into issues.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:17:16

*Thread Reply:* As a general design principle, I would recommend simplifying / aggregating data as it becomes large. It's rarely useful to look at large amounts of raw data on the screen, as you run into the limits of 2d rendering wrt to occlusion, fidelity, and noise resolution.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:17:59

*Thread Reply:* Does that help @Steven?

Steven
2022-06-09 20:18:55

*Thread Reply:* @Halden L (Apple) A little, so are you recommending at most one mark per screen point?

Steven
2022-06-09 20:19:16

*Thread Reply:* and would we use GeometryReader to get that info?

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:21:59

*Thread Reply:* One point per screen point is probably excessive too (from a legibility perspective, if not a performance one)... it would help to get an idea of what you are trying to achieve & what your data looks like

Steven
2022-06-09 20:22:26

*Thread Reply:* We draw a lot of scientific data, some is discrete, other is calculated/continuous

Helge
2022-06-09 20:24:59

*Thread Reply:* Can you give a rough estimate to what number of marks the Charts will scale? Like a 1000? I‚Äôd also like to plot data that comes in every other second in a scroll view, and would probably have to cut off at some point?

Steven
2022-06-09 20:25:43

*Thread Reply:* Our data is available at once, and can have 5000 points. It will be static with no points just the lines

üëç Halden L (Apple)
Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:30:16

*Thread Reply:* cc @Donghao R (Apple)!

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:33:36

*Thread Reply:* It depends on the machine performance and complexity of the chart. It's usually a good idea to test with your actual data and chart to figure out how many points can be drawn with acceptable user experience.

Helge
2022-06-09 20:34:08

*Thread Reply:* No rough scale? Like 100, 1000, 10k, 100k no problem? On say an iPhone 12 Mini?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:36:22

*Thread Reply:* Based on my experience it's about 1000 to 2000 for smooth animations.

üëç Helge
Helge
2022-06-09 20:36:42

*Thread Reply:* Thanks!

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:45:38

*Thread Reply:* You may be interested in the date and number bin apis we added this year: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/charts/numberbins https://developer.apple.com/documentation/charts/datebins. You ca use them to group your data and then summarizing the data in each group/bin.

Steven
2022-06-09 20:46:29

2022-06-09 20:57:33

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:17:47

@Christopher asked > How easy is it to support interactions like pan-to-move and pinch-to-zoom?

üëÄ Raphael, Darrell
Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:20:35

*Thread Reply:* For pan-to-move, you can use a SwiftUI gesture in conjunction with ChartProxy. From the gesture, you get the the pan distance, and then you can use ChartProxy to figure out the pan distance in the data domain. Then, you can set the domain for the X scale with .chartXScale(domain: start + offset...end + offset) , where you can adjust the offset to pan the chart.

üëç Christopher, Liru
Raphael
2022-06-09 20:31:18

*Thread Reply:* Can a similar strategy be used for pinch-to-zoom?

‚òùÔ∏è Christopher
Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:46:32

*Thread Reply:* Yes, you can use a pinch to zoom gesture (or any other gesture) and hook up the events in a similar way.

Christopher
2022-06-09 20:55:25

*Thread Reply:* Without location information (like the new SpatialTapGesture) it would be a bit unnatural as we wouldn't know where to center the zoom, right? MagnificationGesture doesn't provide location information, unless I've missed something

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:59:46

*Thread Reply:* Feel free to file a feedback to SwiftUI for providing location information to gestures.

For now I think you can try implement a UIView with UIPinchGestureRecognizer and then wrap the view with UIViewRepresentable so it can be used in SwiftUI.

üëç Christopher
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:18:10

@Jhonny asked > Can we highlight specific data points and dim the rest; similar to what Health.app does when selecting ‚Äúmin/max‚Äù, ‚Äúlatest‚Äù, etc in Heart Rate and other charts?

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:19:59

*Thread Reply:* absolutely! An easy way to do this is to store the desired highlighted data's ids in a @State and check against that in your ForEach of Marks. Something along the lines of

ForEach(data) { value in BarMark(x: ..., y: ...) .foregroundStyle(value.id == state.highlighted ? Color.red : Color.gray) }

ü§© Jhonny, David
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:20:46

@Alexey asked > Is it possible to use a Chart to display a large amount of data? For example, display a waveform.

Richard W (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:23:03

*Thread Reply:* Yes! https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03HX19UNCQ/p1654798399767779?thread_ts=1654798325.944549&cid=C03HX19UNCQ

} Dominik M (Apple) (https://wwdc22.slack.com/team/U03HW7NSMFT)
<p>You can render curves by sampling data points along the function and then rendering that. You can add interpolation to make the line look smooth. Swift Charts cannot directly render functions.</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03HX19UNCQ/p1654798399767779?thread_ts=1654798325.944549&amp;cid=C03HX19UNCQ
From a thread in <b>#swiftui-lounge</b>
Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:24:52

*Thread Reply:* We generally recommend aggregating very large datasets since there are only so many marks that can be rendered and reasonably read by a user. Swift Charts can process and render a reasonable number of data points.

Alexey
2022-06-09 20:55:52

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:20:56

@Christopher asked > Is there multiple axis support? Logarithmic axis support?

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:21:54

*Thread Reply:* A Swift Charts chart can only have one axis per x and y. Swift Charts supports logarithmic scales.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:22:41

*Thread Reply:* For example, you can specify a log scale on x with

.chartXScale(type: .log)

üëç Christopher
Christopher
2022-06-09 20:23:45

*Thread Reply:* Thanks

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:26:20

*Thread Reply:* You can however, have multiple sets of labels / ticks / grid lines by adding multiple AxisMarks

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:27:25

*Thread Reply:* they will share the same scale, but might be useful for things like displaying both C and F on the same chart

Christopher
2022-06-09 20:29:03

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, we often have requirements to show multiple data sets with varying scales for comparisons

Christopher
2022-06-09 20:29:56

*Thread Reply:* Can you put those different sets of marks on opposite sides of the chart?

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:30:49

*Thread Reply:* In https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03HX19UNCQ/p1654799167892029 I talked about ways to show multiple metrics as separate charts.

<p>@Daniel asked &gt; Is there a way to have multiple scales per chart? Let's say I'm doing weather and I want one line with cloud cover (a 0-100% scale) and rainfall per hour (in, say, mm). The x axis on both of those would be time, but the y axes are different.</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03HX19UNCQ/p1654799167892029
Thread in <b>#swiftui-lounge</b>
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:22:45

@Dennis asked > Swift Charts is really fun! Thanks for adding this, I'm having a blast! :) > > I have one question about the axis labels on charts. When I use the chartXAxis modifier to show custom AxisMarks with an array of values (dates in my case), the chart doesn't show the last value on that axis (the last date). Is it possible to turn that on? > > &gt; // Simple Chart &gt; .chartXAxis { &gt; // data contains two data points with a date. The entire chart only has these two data points &gt; AxisMarks(preset: .extended, values: data.map(\.date)) &gt; } &gt;

‚ù§Ô∏è Dominik M (Apple), Evelyn R (Apple)
Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:24:12

*Thread Reply:* Love to hear it @Dennis! I think I can guess what is going on here. If a label is placed beyond the edge of the axis, (as can be the case with the last value of a list of dates, as it would define the end of your date range) it won't be rendered, as it would run off the edge of the chart.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:25:24

*Thread Reply:* Off the top of my head, solutions may include: adding a bit of "padding" in your date range or switching the axis style.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:25:28

*Thread Reply:* does that help?

Dennis
2022-06-09 20:26:35

*Thread Reply:* Yes, thanks üôÇ

‚ù§Ô∏è Halden L (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:26:07

@Daniel asked > Is there a way to have multiple scales per chart? Let's say I'm doing weather and I want one line with cloud cover (a 0-100% scale) and rainfall per hour (in, say, mm). The x axis on both of those would be time, but the y axes are different.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:28:26

*Thread Reply:* An axis always has one scale. So x and y have one scale. You can have multiple axes to display e.g. temperature in C and F. If you want to show multiple measures, I would recommend multiple charts with aligned x-axes. You can even hide the axis of the upper chart to create a more compact view.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:26:27

@Axel asked > Hey Richard, I'm in love with the Swift Charts framework. I like how we can customise the charts to fit our needs. I noticed some layout issues with the Legend, when there are a lot of items to display, or when the names are long. Do you plan to make the legend Layout automatically wrap/use multiple rows when there is not enough space? I noticed the iCloud design on iOS switches from a HStack to a VStack when the device accessibility is set to true. My feedback with more infos: FB10125848

Richard W (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:26:55

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for your feedback!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:26:39

@Dennis asked > Adding data to charts and the modifiers always requires this .value(_:) function that requires a label key. What exactly is the purpose of that label key? Is it some kind of identifier? Does the label key in a foregroundStyle have to match one in a LineMark, for example (if referencing the same data)? > > Thanks! :)

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:29:47

*Thread Reply:* The label key is used for generating a good default description for the chart for VoiceOver users and the audio graph. For example, if you have x: .value("time", ...), y: .value("sales", ...) , VoiceOver users will hear something like "x axis shows time, y axis shows sales". The label key in foregroundStyle doesn't necessarily need to match LineMark, but it's a good practice to use the same label if the data is the same.

Dennis
2022-06-09 20:30:45

*Thread Reply:* Awesome, thanks for the explanation! üôÇ

*Thread Reply:* Got it! Right now it's 10. Grouping into ForEach's etc would help! If you have a use case that requires more, please file feedback~

üëç Christopher
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:33:07

@Hendrik asked > Swift Charts looks very cool and well designed. What were the inspirations for its API design? It feels very similar in many aspects to ggplot2 which itself is apparently based on "The Grammar of Graphics" book. Was that an inspiration?

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:35:54

*Thread Reply:* Thank you. Its‚Äô great to hear that you enjoy the API.

Swift Charts is a grammar based visualization language, which means charts are composed of building blocks (marks and mark properties) instead of picked from a list of chart types (vertical bar chart, bubble chart, waterfall chart etc). The Grammar of Graphics was hugely influential for many visualization APIs like ggplot, D3, Vega and also Swift Charts.

üëç Matthias
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:33:50

@Frederic asked > Hi, > How can we remove or configure the space between the bars (BarMark) ? > Is it possible to define the bar width ? > Thanks.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:34:26

*Thread Reply:* BarMark has a width parameter that takes a MarkDimension! It can be a fixed value or a ratio (of the space the bar is allocated).

Frederic
2022-06-09 20:53:22

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. When trying, even with ratio = 1 or inset = 0 it seems to always have some space between the bars.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:31:03

*Thread Reply:* @Frederic mind sharing the code? and a screenshot (if you're comfortable)

Frederic
2022-06-09 21:36:48

*Thread Reply:* No problem.

Frederic
2022-06-09 21:37:37

*Thread Reply:* **import** SwiftUI **import** Charts

**struct** Point { **let** month: Date **let** sales: Int **let** color: Color **let** eat: Bool

**init**(month: Date, sales: Int, color: Color, eat: Bool = **false**) { **self**.month = month **self**.sales = sales **self**.color = color **self**.eat = eat } }

**func** date(year: Int, month: Int, day: Int = 1) -&gt; Date { Calendar.current.date(from: DateComponents(year: year, month: month, day: day)) ?? Date() }

**struct** ContentView: View { **var** body: **some** View { Chart(data, id: .month) { p in BarMark( x: .value("Month", p.month, unit: .month), y: .value("Sales", p.sales), width: MarkDimension.ratio(1) ) .foregroundStyle(p.color) .annotation(position: .top) { **if** p.eat { Image(systemName: "seal") } } .annotation(position: .bottom) { **if** p.eat { VStack { Text("") Text("23") } } } } // .chartXAxis { // AxisMarks(values: .stride(by: .month)) { value in // if value.as(Date.self)!.isFirstMonthOfQuarter { // AxisGridLine().foregroundStyle(.black) // AxisTick().foregroundStyle(.black) // AxisValueLabel( // format: .dateTime.month(.narrow) // ) // } else { // AxisGridLine() // } // } // } }

**let** data: [Point] = [ Point(month: date(year: 2021, month: 6), sales: 300, color: Color.yellow), Point(month: date(year: 2021, month: 7), sales: 350, color: Color.yellow), Point(month: date(year: **let** averageValue = 137 }

**extension** Date { **var** isFirstMonthOfQuarter: Bool { Calendar.current.component(.month, from: **self**) % 3 == 1 } }

**struct** ContentView_Previews: PreviewProvider { static **var** previews: **some** View {

ContentView().frame(width: 400, height: 100.0)

} }

Frederic
2022-06-09 21:38:42

*Thread Reply:* None

image.png
Frederic
2022-06-09 21:39:49

*Thread Reply:* The screenshot is from the SwiftUI preview.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:40:40

*Thread Reply:* cc @Donghao R (Apple)!

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:43:04

*Thread Reply:* this is a pixel boundary rendering artifact. One solution is to make the width just a tadddd over 1 so they overlap just a bit

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:47:37

*Thread Reply:* It's a rendering artifact that happens when the bars doesn't align with pixel boundaries. There are a couple of ways to address it: ‚Ä¢ As Halden mentioned, you can make the bars slightly wider (with something like .inset(-1) or .ratio(1.01)) ‚Ä¢ You can also tweak the width of the plot area (with .chartPlotStyle { $0.frame(width: plotAreaWidth) }) based on the number of bars, so that the bars are aligned exactly with pixel boundaries. This is more complex to do, but will give the best result.

üíØ Halden L (Apple), Joseph
Frederic
2022-06-09 21:52:52

*Thread Reply:* Thanks ! üëç

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:37:11

@David asked > Do you have any suggestions for displaying "goal progress" data? Saw in earlier Q&A that radial/rings charts are not supported, but other types could be used. Looking for visualization similar to Health activity rings. Thinking about 3 bars normalized to % of progress toward goal.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:38:30

*Thread Reply:* You could make a chart with three bars one for each category. If you set the scale to have a domain from e.g. 0 to 100, then the length of a bar indicates the progress towards a goal. A horizontal bar chart could work well.

David
2022-06-09 20:41:55

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Dominik M (Apple) that's exactly what I was thinking, too. But unsure on upper bound of chart when goal is exceeded. For rings, if my steps goal is 5000 and I actually take 12000, then it would show 240% for that bar.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:47:24

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs an interesting consideration. You could have a chart that extends beyond 5000 but adds a vertical RuleMark to annotate the goal.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:48:06

*Thread Reply:* Since you may show different metrics (e.g. steps and distance), you may want to normalize them to % of goal so they have the same scale/axis.

David
2022-06-09 21:29:55

*Thread Reply:* Thanks again, I'll give this a whirl!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:40:14

@Joseph asked > Hi everyone! Is there a suggested "update rate" that you'd recommend for real-time charts? When trying this out on a simulated iPhone, I quickly approach 90%+ CPU usage if I try to update a line graph more than 40 times/second (For example, when trying to visualize a simulated accelerometer).

Steven
2022-06-09 20:40:56

*Thread Reply:* Humans have a hard time with anything more than 10Hz anyway...

Richard W (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:45:50

*Thread Reply:* We recommend benchmarking your app to find the right balance between the update rate and the amount of data on your line chart. We'd also appreciate feedback through Feedback Assistant for your use case!

Joseph
2022-06-09 21:04:17

*Thread Reply:* If I may follow up: if we're to alter the drawing rate so it adds new data points in batches, does Charts have built-in functionality for that, or would we need to set up the Combine publishers manually? I didn't see anything in the documentation, but I understand the docs could also be in beta

Steven
2022-06-09 21:05:03

*Thread Reply:* Honestly at 40Hz I think you're looking at game semantics, i.e. Metal or at least SceneKit

Joseph
2022-06-09 21:07:30

*Thread Reply:* Yeah when I previously worked on the project that would use my own pre-"Swift Charts" charts. I experimented with rendering the charts using Metal, and that was not a very productive week üòÖ

Steven
2022-06-09 21:08:10

*Thread Reply:* You would need to write a small framework, but SceneKit (or even SpriteKit?) could do a lot of the work

Steven
2022-06-09 21:08:49

*Thread Reply:* But I think you need to isolate your fast-updating surfaces and not drag all of UIKit/SwiftUI into it otherwise the performance will crash

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:42:34

@Christopher asked > We have data that doesn't necessarily progress linearly from one point to the next, for example the x and y values could either increase or decrease from one point to the next. Would those points be linked as if they were points on a path or would it upset the system?

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:43:31

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôm not sure I fully got the question but you can either draw points as separate with PointMark or linked with a LineMark . Adding linked points is well supported by Swift Charts.

Steven
2022-06-09 20:45:43

*Thread Reply:* Sounds like "can I do XY scatter with joined lines"

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:48:37

*Thread Reply:* Ahh. The answer is yes. Use a LineMark .

2022-06-09 20:50:18

*Thread Reply:* Thanks

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:48:06

@Kent asked > I have a horizontal bar chart with two Text overlay annotations on each bar, one aligned leading and one aligned trailing. When the bars are short the annotations overlap and eventually truncate. Is there an easy way to hide overlayed annotations when the bars are too short to accommodate their intrinsic widths or should I explore other layout configurations (e.g. one annotation with an HStack containing two Text views spanning the context target region width)?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:51:32

*Thread Reply:* There isn't a way to hide overlayed annotations right now, but feel free to file a feedback üôÇ

In this situation, you can explore other layout options as you mentioned. For example, a single annotation with HStack { Text(...); Spacer(); Text(...) }

Kent
2022-06-09 20:52:30

*Thread Reply:* Thanks.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:49:44

@Hendrik asked > Is there a way for external developers to extend Swift Charts and add new chart types that aren't supported out of the box, for example pie charts, or charts with 3D styling?

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:51:40

*Thread Reply:* You can create custom marks but they need to be cartesian. So you can make e.g. a candlestick or boxplot. Swift Charts does not support pie charts or 3D charts. See https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03HX19UNCQ/p1654618060787259 for a discussion of alternatives.

} Betsy L - Technology Evangelism (Apple) (https://wwdc22.slack.com/team/U03DJTAUPHT)
<p>Swift Charts üßµ</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03HX19UNCQ/p1654618060787259
Thread in <b>#swiftui-lounge</b>
Hendrik
2022-06-09 21:12:51

*Thread Reply:* Thank you. So I would assume a 2D bar graph with a fake 3D effect for the bar marks should be easily doable. But no circular graphs (for now).

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:23:31

*Thread Reply:* Yes, I would agree with that.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:54:41

@Robert asked > Is there a method to modify or specify the label style of a chart? For instance, my chart includes price averages for home heating oil. I want to clearly display on the label that the Double is in dollar format on the Y axis. > > At this time, when I attempted a brief demo app it simply made the Y axis label as an Int.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:57:26

*Thread Reply:* @Robert sorry for the late reply! Yes, there are a few options here. You can use AxisMarks(format: FormatStyle) or AxisValueLabel(format: FormatStyle) or AxisValueLabel { Text(\(..., format: ...)) }

üôå David
Robert
2022-06-09 20:58:03

*Thread Reply:* ‚ù§Ô∏è Perfect, thanks!

üôÇ Halden L (Apple)
Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:58:08

*Thread Reply:* If your units are more verbose, a design alternative is to clarify them in the title or headline of your chart, to save horizontal space on the y axis.

Robert
2022-06-09 20:58:56

*Thread Reply:* At this time I'm tracking price averages per month over the last 12 months, the user will have the ability to toggle between the last 12 and 6 months. The X axis is the Month, the Y axis is the Average Price.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:59:48

*Thread Reply:* the former is likely enough then, makes sense!

2022-06-09 20:57:04

@James asked > Can charts be used in the new Preview option to see a live chart in the preview without needing to go to that screen? Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:57:42

*Thread Reply:* Can you clarify what you mean by the preview option? Charts can be in any SwiftUI View.

2022-06-09 21:09:36

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:24:10

*Thread Reply:* You can use Swift Charts to draw live data.

2022-06-09 21:25:32

*Thread Reply:* But does it update for the preview, or when you've loaded the view with the chart?

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:37:45

*Thread Reply:* Swift Charts behaves like other Views and updates the same way.

James
2022-06-09 21:39:28

*Thread Reply:* So is the contextMenu preview a View in its own right?

Dominik M (Apple)

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:00:29

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:02:17

@Frederic asked > Hi, > Sorry if this was already asked, but how can I add a text or SF Symbol at the top of a vertical BarMark ? > (I did not found the information at https://developer.apple.com/documentation/charts/ ) ? > Thanks.

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:04:02

*Thread Reply:* You can use the annotation modifier to add an annotation on top of the bar, where the content of the annotation is a SF Symbol image. Here's an example: BarMark(...) .annotation(position: .top) { Image(systemName: "sfsymbol_name") } Note that you can also use Text or other views as the content of the annotation.

Frederic
2022-06-09 21:09:53

*Thread Reply:* Parfect ! This is amazing how configurable the Charts are. It will save me a lot of time in my application! Thanks.

‚ù§Ô∏è Evelyn R (Apple), Donghao R (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:12:34

@Emilie asked > The charts are amazing! I saw the example for the Interval Bar Chart in the docs and it got me thinking I could represent a simple weekly view of a student's course schedule if I flipped the axis. I made a proof of concept and it worked really well! I calculate the duration of a meeting in minutes to create the size of the BarMark using yStart and yEnd. Is this a good way to do this or can it be achieved with just the start date time and end date time? I also had to reverse the chartYScale to get the AM meetings to apear first, not sure if that is expected or not. > > struct Series: Identifiable { > let courseName: String > let meetings: [Meeting] > var id: String { courseName } > } > struct Meeting { > let startDate: Date > let endDate: Date > let startMinute: Double //Minutes since 7am > let endMinute: Double > } > > Chart(data) { series in > ForEach(series.meetings, id: .startDate) { element in > BarMark( > x: .value("Course", element.startDate, unit: .day), > yStart: .value("Start Time", element.startMinute), > yEnd: .value("End Time", element.endMinute) > ).annotation(position: .overlay, alignment: .top) { > VStack { > Text(series.courseName).font(.caption) > Text(element.startDate.stringValue(dateFormat: .time)).font(.caption) > } > } > } > .cornerRadius(8.0) > .foregroundStyle(by: .value("Course", series.courseName)) > } .chartYAxis { > AxisMarks(position: .leading, values: .stride(by: 60)) { axis in > AxisTick() > AxisGridLine() > AxisValueLabel(centered: false) { > if axis.index+7 < 13 { > Text("(axis.index+7) AM") > } else { > Text("((axis.index+7)-12) PM") > } > } > } > }.chartXAxis { > AxisMarks(position: .top, values: daysOfTheWeek) { _ in > AxisGridLine() > AxisTick() > AxisValueLabel(centered: true) > } > }.chartYScale(domain: .automatic(reversed: true))

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:13:21

*Thread Reply:* @Emilie beautiful!! You can use Date here instead of converting to integer minutes and it should go top to bottom by default.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:13:26

*Thread Reply:* cc @Donghao R (Apple)

Emilie
2022-06-09 21:13:43

*Thread Reply:* None

2022-06-09 21:15:35

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:15:36

2022-06-09 21:15:54

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:16:59

*Thread Reply:* sorry, I was trying to answer your question about the y axis

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:17:18

*Thread Reply:* Int and Double will go bottom up (low to high) while dates will go top down (early to late)

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:17:51

*Thread Reply:* lmk if that helps / if you have follow-up Qs

2022-06-09 21:18:01

ü§£ Halden L (Apple)
Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:24:22

*Thread Reply:* Ok I understand now. I think you're approach is good! (turning it into a number and then applying a reverse and customizing the axis labels). This is a clever solution, I dig it.

The problem with the startDate and endDate approach is that its interpreting the dates including the date, so your Y axis became a mirror the X axis.

James
2022-06-09 21:24:31

*Thread Reply:* Very cool alternative use of Charts

üíØ Halden L (Apple)

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:38:45

*Thread Reply:* You can try positioning the legend on the trailing edge of the chart using the chartLegend modifier

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:39:24

*Thread Reply:* The default color scale is currently as follows: all system colors

.systemBlue, .green, .orange, .purple, .red, .teal, .yellow

*Thread Reply:* (btw @Dennis if you don't want to add extra points, you can adjust the chartXScale(domain:) or range manually and achieve the same result.)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:15:43

@Thomas asked > Can we transform a mark when the user presses and releases it, like we could do with a ButtonStyle. If not, we can probably use an overlay, but can we change the size of marks without changing their values (for example with a scale effect)?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:18:20

*Thread Reply:* Currently we don't have a scaleEffect modifier. You can use something like width: .fixed(hovering ? 100 : 80) in BarMark constructor. This will make the bar wider when hovering is true.

Thomas
2022-06-09 21:19:18

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, I think I can make it work then!

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:19:39

@Aaron asked > Hi, > I'm curious on how Charts handles time based data e.g. temperature over a day when data can be received at any point of the day, not a set interval apart? Some chart libraries that have previously existed did not handle this and just spaced out data incorrectly.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:21:29

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Aaron! Charts handles Date as a continuous variable, so this should be fine. If you do want to treat the data as spaced out evenly (e.g., exactly one measurement per day) you can tell the framework to do so by using the unit parameter in a value

Aaron
2022-06-09 21:22:01

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! I definitely don‚Äôt want it spaced evenly. Great to hear it just handles it approriately.

üôå Halden L (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:24:25

@Aaron asked > Hi, > > I've got a set of data I wish to chart that is discrete states over time, for example on/off states of a light, or an enumeration a door lock's state. (example: https://twitter.com/aaronpearce/status/1527452719027728384?s=21&t=ux-SjhyOSmO89k0u4LfjA).|https://twitter.com/aaronpearce/status/1527452719027728384?s=21&t=ux-SjhyOSmO89k0u4LfjA). > > How would you recommend tackling this chart? RectangleMarks?

2022-06-09 21:24:53

*Thread Reply:* Yes. A Rectangle or Bar Mark.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:25:37

@Steven asked > What's the best way to use ChartRenderer to draw to a CGContext with slightly different styles (e.g. draw shapes as hollow, or dashed lines, etc)?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:27:44

*Thread Reply:* Currently there's no API to draw marks with styles other than what's supported in ShapeStyle. Feel free to file a feature request via Feedback Assistant.

Steven
2022-06-09 21:28:57

*Thread Reply:* @Donghao R (Apple) Basically we'd like to replicate our current draw-to-PDF behaviors which favor line art, simple coloring, and optional line dashes for monochrome

Steven
2022-06-09 21:29:14

*Thread Reply:* As distinct from the on-screen styling

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:34:12

*Thread Reply:* That sounds very cool! I'll file an internal feature request for this.

Steven
2022-06-09 21:36:01

*Thread Reply:* @Donghao R (Apple) So does that mean we can't pass in a ChartView and apply styles just for the rendering?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:40:05

*Thread Reply:* No, currently there isn't a way to configure styling of the renderer itself. You could try an approach like exporting the rendered content as PDF or SVG and apply the styling by transforming the resulting vector graphics.

Steven
2022-06-09 21:40:15

*Thread Reply:* ok, thank you

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:33:09

@Aaron asked > Is it possible to assign a gradient between specific LineMarks? E.g. to show a change in value in temperature from cold to hot?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:35:49

*Thread Reply:* You can draw an AreaMark with .foregroundStyle(gradient) below the two lines.

Aaron
2022-06-09 21:36:48

*Thread Reply:* Thanks!

Aaron
2022-06-09 21:36:58

*Thread Reply:* Would this change the line or apply an area under them?

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:40:46

*Thread Reply:* It will add an area under them, the lines will be intact.

Aaron
2022-06-09 21:41:32

*Thread Reply:* Is it possible to apply a gradient direct to the line?

Aaron
2022-06-09 21:44:32

*Thread Reply:* More as a function of the temp over time (left to right) on the line itself than just decorative

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:50:22

*Thread Reply:* You can use .foregroundStyle(gradient) on the LineMark as well.

Donghao R (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:50:47

*Thread Reply:* with a LinearGradient that goes from left to right.

Aaron
2022-06-09 21:51:17

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs perfect!

üôå Donghao R (Apple)
Aaron
2022-06-09 21:51:17

*Thread Reply:* thanks

‚ù§Ô∏è Donghao R (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:37:19

@Frederic asked > Hi again, > Are Charts planned to be available also on iOS 15 ? > Thanks.

Dominik M (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:38:25

*Thread Reply:* Swift Charts is iOS 16 only since Swift Charts relies on features that are not available in earlier versions.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:50:13

@Adam asked > What's the best way to that we can use Swift Charts in a predominately UIKit app?

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:50:41

*Thread Reply:* @Adam, Sara has a session on this where she adds a Swift Chart to a UIKit app üôÇ

https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10072/

Apple Developer
Use SwiftUI with UIKit - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how to take advantage of the power of SwiftUI in your UIKit app. Build custom UICollectionView and UITableView cells seamlessly...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10072/
‚ù§Ô∏è Sara F (Apple), Adam
Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:51:26

*Thread Reply:* oh hi @Sara F (Apple)

üëã:skin_tone_2: Sara F (Apple)
Sara F (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:53:14

*Thread Reply:* Yes the new UIHostingConfiguration lets you use SwiftUI in cells and UIHostingController has some new ways to track size changes that make it easier to use it in stack views or in embedded view controller! Definitely check out the talk, anywhere I talk about using a SwiftUI view you can use a Chart as well!

üíØ Halden L (Apple)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 21:59:01

@Matthaus asked > Is it possible to share one of the axis between 2 charts or have 2 subcharts on the same axis, eg share x-axis have have 2 different y-axies on either side with their own independent domain range. > > Or have a plot when another plot to its right that shares the y-axis but has its own x-axis (commonly used when drawing a heatmap to show a histogram attached on the side)

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:00:23

*Thread Reply:* @Matthaus Hope I'm understanding your question correctly. You can set specify two charts to have the same chartScale and chartAxis using the appropriate modifiers, but we don't support dual scales on the same chart

üëç Matthaus

2022-06-09 22:00:14

@here Wow and another one for the books! Our time for the Swift Charts Q&A session has come to an end. ‚ú®

Huge thanks to @Richard W (Apple) for leading this and to our Swift Charts team for spending time with us!

But wait there is more...stick around! Our Q&A with the Xcode Previews team is... well.. RIGHT HERE....RIGHT NOW! ü•≥

Our friendly engineer @Kevin C (Apple) is leading it. Let‚Äôs all welcome him! üëè:skintone3:

Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:00:14

Hello! üéâ üëã I‚Äôm Kevin and I work on the SwiftUI Previews team and we‚Äôre excited to answer your questions!

Please click the shortcut lightning bolt :shortcut: at the bottom of the channel, and choose ‚ÄúAsk a Question‚Äù to submit yours. So please, ask away!

To give some expectation of the kinds of questions we‚Äôre going to answer here in the lounge, we‚Äôll focus on questions about features, capabilities, and strategies using previews. We won‚Äôt be posting questions about specific projects or configurations. If you have one of those cases, we‚Äôd love to see it, so please open a feedback request. We‚Äôll give you some tips for filing great SwiftUI previews bugs in this lounge. So please don‚Äôt post any previews diagnostics files or sample projects here in Slack, you can attach those to your feedback.

OK are you ready? Here we go!

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è:skin_tone_3: Evelyn R (Apple)
üèÉ:skin_tone_3: Evelyn R (Apple)
üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Anupama P (Apple), Ian H (Apple), Max, Zhang, Marcelo

üôè:skin_tone_2: Chris J (Apple)
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:13:10

@Karim-Pierre asked > My Previews take generally a long time to render, often failing (timeout) and sometimes it's quicker to just launch a run on the simulator. Also, it takes some huge place on disk (40GB+). Any hint to optimise all this and make the Previews quick, light and reactive?

Jonathan P (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:13:25

*Thread Reply:* If you're experiencing long times to render there might be something specific about your setup. Filing a feedback with a sysdiagnose taken while the preview is taking the long time to render would be very helpful for us to diagnose this.

As far as general tips to keep things fast, it helps to break up you views into smaller components where possible. And if your app project itself takes a long time to build, then it could be very helpful to split your Swift UI views out into a separate framework target so they could be built without the burden of the rest of the project.

Lowell
2022-06-09 22:16:07

*Thread Reply:* @Jonathan P (Apple) Could you elaborate on separating out the SwiftUI views? I am currently working on an objc app and adding new SwiftUI screens, but the builds can sometimes take a while because the rest of the app is somewhat large. Anything I can do to speed that up without having to copy paste the SwiftUI code to a blank SwiftUI project would be awesome

Karim-Pierre
2022-06-09 22:16:34

*Thread Reply:* @Jonathan P (Apple) Yes I was just thinking about this last advice ‚Äî although perhaps with a Package rather than a framework.

Lowell
2022-06-09 22:16:36

*Thread Reply:* (I don't even know objc really so I try to stay out of it)

Kristofer K (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:19:00

*Thread Reply:* @Lowell I think the general theme is trying to focus on building as little as possible. If you can build out those new SwiftUI views in a framework / package, you can opt to build just that package rather than all of the app.

Lowell
2022-06-09 22:20:09

*Thread Reply:* I've considered doing that, but have never dove into creating a framework or package. But i'm tempted now..

‚ù§Ô∏è Kristofer K (Apple), Jonathan P (Apple)
Jonathan P (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:26:54

*Thread Reply:* Yup, packages would be fine, too. It's even easier to use them in Xcode now. The larger point is to break out the parts that need Swift UI into their own targets that can be built independently. It might even help to have a separate "previewing" app target that you link your Swift UI views into instead of your main app. It all depends on your setup, of course. The tl;dr is that Previews needs to build some target to get its work done. If your whole app target is large and slow to build then it will be the bottleneck for previews that you can investigate.

Of course you might find other bugs on our end that slow things down. Please file feedback reports with sysdiagnosen! :)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:14:43

@Christian asked > As of Xcode 13, there are some gotchas with SwiftUI Previews and custom build configurations not named Debug or Release. > > ‚Ä¢ SwiftUI Previews are not compiled-out unless the active build configuration is exactly named Release. > ‚Ä¢ Source files under the Preview Content directory are compiled-out for non-debug builds (whether this is looking for the active build configuration to not-be-named ‚ÄúDebug‚Äù or whether it‚Äôs based on code optimization levels, I do not know) > > So, what this means is‚Ä¶ > > ‚Ä¢ If you have a custom build configuration, say a ‚ÄúStaging‚Äù or ‚ÄúBeta‚Äù or whatever, which is essentially a variant of ‚ÄúRelease‚Äù‚Ä¶. > ‚Ä¢ And if you have SwiftUI Previews in your app‚Ä¶ > ‚Ä¢ And if those previews are not wrapped in #if DEBUG directives‚Ä¶ > ‚Ä¢ And if you have source code to support SwiftUI Previews stashed under the ‚ÄúPreview Content‚Äù directory‚Ä¶ > > Then your project will likely fail to build, as the previews will not be compiled out, but they will depend upon development asset code in ‚ÄúPreview Content‚Äù that is compiled out. > > Do you know if this is resolved in Xcode 14?

üòÆ Karim-Pierre
‚ûï Jeremy
Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:14:53

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the feedback! Right now the recommendation is to limit the Preview Content folder (which is really just a convenience for the DEVELOPMENT_ASSET_PATHS build setting) to assets like asset catalogs, preview data, etc.

For code, we recommend you continue to keep it in your normal source paths, but to wrap with #if . Note: the compiler will normally remove any preview providers from the final binary without needing the #if, but the #if is a guarantee it won‚Äôt be included.

Christian
2022-06-09 22:16:58

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs specifically preview data that we are using in the previews. The problem is our Staging target, and the mismatch between what is being compiled out for Previews vs Preview Content.

Christian
2022-06-09 22:17:32

*Thread Reply:* It seems like those two should agree on what is being compiled out.

Jeremy
2022-06-09 22:18:07

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôve also had this problem, I made this SO post for it. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63078880/why-does-archive-fail-if-there-is-code-for-swiftui-previews-in-the-preview-conte

Stack Overflow
Why does Archive fail if there is code for SwiftUI Previews in the Preview Content folder?
In my SwiftUI app, I have put some sample model objects in Xcode's &amp;quot;Preview Content&amp;quot; folder. I only access them in my SwiftUI PreviewProviders. My understanding is that the code/assets in...
Original URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63078880/why-does-archive-fail-if-there-is-code-for-swiftui-previews-in-the-preview-conte
Jeremy
2022-06-09 22:18:26

*Thread Reply:* I filed FB8969539 for this issue.

‚úÖ Christian
Christian
2022-06-09 22:18:43

*Thread Reply:* Yep, that‚Äôs exactly it Jeremy.

Christian
2022-06-09 22:19:25

*Thread Reply:* So annoying because we sometime forget to wrap our new views in the DEBUG check. I need to invest in some script / linter to check this, but I was hoping this problem would go away in Xcode 14.

‚ûï Jeremy
Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:20:22

*Thread Reply:* If you don‚Äôt put any code in Preview Content, then the compiler will usually be able to correctly remove any branches of code used only for previews.

Christian
2022-06-09 22:21:48

*Thread Reply:* But it is code, and that seems very useful. Do you have other recommendations?

Screen Shot 2022-06-09 at 4.20.51 PM.png
Christian
2022-06-09 22:22:36

*Thread Reply:* I think you‚Äôre recommending to move that code out of Preview Content and ü§û that it is removed from release builds?

üëç Kevin C (Apple)
Christian
2022-06-09 22:23:47

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôll give that a shot. Thanks!

Jeremy
2022-06-09 22:24:27

*Thread Reply:* How would it get removed from the release builds? I don‚Äôt know of any other mechanism other than #if DEBUG

Christian
2022-06-09 22:26:01

*Thread Reply:* I think that‚Äôs what is being recommended ‚Äì move the code out of Preview Content and manually wrap the entire code in an if DEBUG check.

Christian
2022-06-09 22:27:20

*Thread Reply:* But it seems less than ideal since Preview Content is built for exactly this use case. What is compiled out should match between PreviewProvider and Preview Content.

Jeremy
2022-06-09 22:27:55

*Thread Reply:* Fully agreed.

Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:34:03

*Thread Reply:* The compiler optimizes by removing non-public symbols that aren‚Äôt referenced from any top level code. This will remove most preview code that is not referenced by other public or used types.

Jeremy
2022-06-09 22:44:05

*Thread Reply:* Just to clarify my understanding, you are saying that it‚Äôs not supported use case to have code inside the Preview Contents folder that will be stripped out in Release builds?

Jeremy
2022-06-09 22:47:47

*Thread Reply:* Note that this contradicts what was implied in WWDC 2020's session ‚ÄúStructure your app for SwiftUI previews‚Äù.

> ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs great about Development Assets is they apply not only to files like Asset catalogs, but also to code. Let‚Äôs look at what‚Äôs inside that preview content folder that we just added.‚Äù > > By using the navigator, we can look inside and see two Swift files. These Swift files contain code that I only need for development and debugging and testing my app, and I don‚Äôt want to include these when my app is actually deployed. https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10149/?time=637

Apple Developer
Structure your app for SwiftUI previews - WWDC20 - Videos - Apple Developer
When you use SwiftUI previews during development, you can quickly create apps that are more flexible and maintainable. Discover ways to...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10149/?time=637
Christian
2022-06-09 22:52:06

*Thread Reply:* ‚Ä¢ SwiftUI previews - compiled out of exactly ‚ÄúRelease‚Äù ‚Ä¢ Preview Content ‚Äì NOT compiled out of ‚ÄúDebug‚Äù Ultimately it seems odd to me that these two things have different strategies. Everything discussed in this thread is fine but we have to acknowledge that everything we‚Äôre currently doing (#if DEBUG) or recommended in this thread is a workaround for the disconnect between the above bullet points.

Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:23:48

*Thread Reply:* Great thoughts and responses everyone!

> Just to clarify my understanding, you are saying that it‚Äôs not supported use case to have code inside the Preview Contents folder that will be stripped out in Release builds? It‚Äôs not unsupported ( üôÇ ) to put code in Preview Content, but we‚Äôve found it to work best when Preview Content is limited to assets.

> Note that this contradicts what was implied in WWDC 2020's session ‚ÄúStructure your app for SwiftUI previews‚Äù üôÉ

Jeremy
2022-06-09 23:29:24

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the reply @Kevin C (Apple)

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:19:18

@Lowell asked > Are there any new SwiftUI Preview tools for previewing views on devices of varying os versions? For example viewing how a view would look on an iOS 16 device vs iOS 15 that uses the compiler checks

‚ù§Ô∏è Roman, Kyle
Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:19:31

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the question! There‚Äôs not currently a variant mode in the canvas for different iOS versions. However, there is a neat solution! If you have a physical iPhone that is running iOS 15, you can use on-device previews to see your simulator preview in the canvas (running iOS 16) and the preview running on device (running iOS 15). And any changes you make will automatically be updated in both places at the same time!

If you have other use cases for seeing multiple OS versions, please file a Feedback Request so we can take a look, thanks!

ü§Ø Christopher, Roman, Daria
üò± Roman

2022-06-09 22:22:18

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:20:54

@Zulfiqar asked > What's the best practice for working with Core Data and SwiftUI previews, such that we don't end up interacting with the actual store data?

Jonathan P (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:21:50

*Thread Reply:* Core Data supports pointing to in-memory storage which won't need the file system and would work great in any situation where you don't want to persist the changes permanently, even in Previews.

https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/CoreData/PersistentStoreFeatures.html

developer.apple.com
Core Data Programming Guide: Persistent Store Types and Behaviors
Explains how to manage objects using the Core Data framework.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/CoreData/PersistentStoreFeatures.html

2022-06-09 22:37:08

Perhaps you could handle this specific case by displaying a dedicated message so that the developer precisely knows what the preview is waiting for.

Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:26:03

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the feedback @Frederic, that‚Äôs a great idea. We‚Äôve been tracking a number of issues related to type checking, so we‚Äôre on it! üôÇ

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:27:09

@Christian asked > Views within an extension aren't always exposed to Previews. This will create a compile issue: > > &gt; enum MyNameSpace { } &gt; extension MyNameSpace { &gt; struct MyContainerView: View { &gt; var body: some View { MyChildView() } &gt; } &gt; struct MyChildView: View { &gt; var body: some View {Text("MyView") } &gt; } &gt; } &gt; &gt; &gt; struct ContentView_Previews: PreviewProvider { &gt; static var previews: some View { &gt; MyNameSpace.MyContainerView() &gt; } &gt; } &gt; > > Is this a known issue? I'm hoping it's not expected. üôÉ

Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:27:37

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the question! Ha, yes, definitely not expected üôÇ

This is a known issue that we are actively looking at. In the meantime, a workaround is to add a typealias inside of the struct that references the other view. For example in your example I added typealias MyChildView = MyNameSpace.MyChildView inside of MyContainerView and the preview renders.

:gratitude_thank_you: Christian
Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:28:40

Thanks for all of the great questions about Previews so far! We‚Äôre having fun, are you? Just a reminder: we‚Äôre only answering questions specific to SwiftUI Previews in this lounge.

If you still have questions about the SwiftUI Framework please post them in the <https://developer.apple.com/forums/ |Developer Forums> or refer to the second lab for SwiftUI. There is still time to request! You can submit your questions today before 6PM Pacific time.

developer.apple.com
SwiftUI &amp; UI Frameworks - Topics - WWDC22
Build interfaces that feel right at home on Apple platforms.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/topics/swiftui-ui-frameworks/#current
üôè Lior
üôè:skin_tone_3: Evelyn R (Apple)
üì£ Evelyn R (Apple), Romy, Lior
SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:37:25

@Tyler asked > Question re the layout inspector inspecting swiftui - curious if there are public/sanctioned ways to introspect a swiftui view for details, similar to what is presented in the details panel (on the right when selecting a view).

Kristofer K (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:40:04

*Thread Reply:* Hey Tyler, great question! The current recommendation is to attach to the process and use the view debugger.

The runtime view debugger does not provide the same level of detail that you get when using the inspector in Previews ‚Äì are there specific details that you are looking for in the view debugger?

Yevhen
2022-06-09 22:44:32

*Thread Reply:* @Kristofer K (Apple) Can you suggest how to use background(color.red.ignoreSafeArea()) together with .cornerRadius? It just dont work :(

Tyler
2022-06-09 22:45:07

*Thread Reply:* Sorry, I realized that this question wasn‚Äôt actually preview-specific until after I posted. Previews are great for eyeballing layout and validating behavior, but I use the inspector to validate specific fonts, frames, etc. Historically we‚Äôve used internal tooling for inspection against UIViews, etc. from tests and interactive inspectors. We‚Äôre rethinking this approach as we migrate to SwiftUI, but still curious if there‚Äôs a public way to ask an arbitrary view for this info. The Xcode inspector seems to be able to focus on an arbitrary view and dump useful info.

Tyler
2022-06-09 22:48:22

*Thread Reply:* Re previews and eyeballing - I take this back. There‚Äôs a lot I can check in non-interactive mode.

üôå Kristofer K (Apple)
Tyler
2022-06-09 22:49:15

*Thread Reply:* However, there are still other cases in which I‚Äôd like to have access to this type of general info outside of the context of previews.

Kristofer K (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:50:42

*Thread Reply:* In particular, what level of detail are you looking for with the font? i.e. Is it a custom font that you‚Äôre trying to validate or are you trying to make sure something is actually using a system font like .heading

Tyler
2022-06-09 22:53:32

*Thread Reply:* We use custom fonts, yes. Consider the scenario - we have a large app; currently, I (or say, a designer) can nav to an arbitrary screen, open up our in-process inspector; focus on a view and inspect its attributes. All without connecting via Xcode and attaching.

Tyler
2022-06-09 22:55:13

*Thread Reply:* My assumption here is that we‚Äôre entering a new world with new tools and introspection like this isn‚Äôt straight forward. But was still curious if there was something I‚Äôm missing.

Kristofer K (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:00:59

*Thread Reply:* Gotcha. To answer your question, I don‚Äôt believe that level of introspection is available but we‚Äôre interested in hearing more about what you‚Äôre looking for. Could you please open a feedback request to help us track interest in a feature like that?

Tyler
2022-06-09 23:03:50

*Thread Reply:* Absolutely! Thanks.

SwiftUI - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:42:10

@Lior asked > Adding border to views when developing helps debugging/developing your code. > Adding borders to every view in the screen can be tiring. > > Is there a way currently to automatically add borders to all the views in the screen with the press of a button/setting?

Daisy H (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:42:28

*Thread Reply:* If you'd like to see the borders of each view in the preview you can use the non-interactive mode then in the menu bar go to Editor > Canvas > Show View Bounds. Additionally, you can toggle "Show Clipped Views" in the same menu to show or hide views that extend beyond the edges of the preview.

üôå Todd, Karim-Pierre, Lior, Max, Adam, Florian
üëç Mayra M, Lior, Tim, Christopher, Ran, Pavan
Lior
2022-06-09 22:53:05

*Thread Reply:* Thank you! ‚ù§Ô∏è

I've seen that Previews got a substantial update in Xcode 14 and I was surprised to see this was not addressed.

üëÄ Rhys
Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:46:03

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for the feedback. Yes, we know this is a common issue and are still finding the best path forward to solve it. Thanks for the patience!

üëç Radu, Max, Rhys
Tim
2022-06-09 22:50:44

*Thread Reply:* as far as i rememeber, .module is only generated when a Swift package target has resources. so it might be a better workaround to add an empty file to a package üôÇ https://developer.apple.com/documentation/packagedescription/target/resources

Radu
2022-06-09 23:09:54

*Thread Reply:* ü§û:skintone3:Thank you for the answer!

‚ûï Lowell

2022-06-09 22:51:08

*Thread Reply:* There is not currently a way to have the preview canvas match the size of the device being previewed, though it is a known request. Feel free to file a Feedback request to help us track interest in that feature, thanks!

Frederic
2022-06-09 22:57:57

*Thread Reply:* OK, Thanks.

Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:54:16

While we‚Äôre looking at the questions you submitted, here‚Äôs a common question we‚Äôre seeing‚Ä¶ ‚≠ê ‚ùì

Q: How do I see multiple previews at the same time with Xcode 14?

A: Each view in the PreviewProvider now shows in its own tab, and there are two ways to see multiple configurations in one tab.

First, you can see multiple previews in the same tab for variations in device settings by using the new variants mode, accessible from the bottom bar of the canvas.

Second, for multiple previews of the same view but with different inputs, you can make a single preview of a List or VStack that contains those different configurations. This is particularly helpful with rows of a List as the List will also show those views with the correct list styling and metrics.

We‚Äôd love feedback if you have a unique case that you don‚Äôt think is covered by the current solutions!

üëÄ Karim-Pierre
Artyom
2022-06-09 22:57:55

*Thread Reply:* How about Generate button that creates previews in code for the current configuration? üòù üëÄ

Christian
2022-06-09 22:58:26

*Thread Reply:* Another great reason for using .previewDisplayName("Descriptive Title")

image.png
‚ûï Jordan
üî• Artyom, Shannon, Mayra M

Being able to rapidly iterate on a view to get it just how I want completely changes my approach to things. Now I just dive in, and start coding, and continually refine until it‚Äôs perfect. With .xibs, I would give up far before the point of perfection.

üôå MEHDI
Kevin C (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:29:11

Thanks for all the questions rolling in!

While more questions roll in‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs Pro Tip Time! üèÜ üïë

We love to get bugs for previews through the Feedback app. Filing a good bug for previews means including a couple key attachments for us:

‚Ä¢ Most importantly, please attach the previews diagnostics that Xcode generates, accessible from the error banner that appears in the canvas: ‚ó¶ 1. Click the ‚ÄúDiagnostics‚Äù button in that banner (or if the banner is missing you can use the menu: Editor > Canvas > Diagnostics) ‚ó¶ 2. In the sheet that appears, click ‚ÄúGenerate Report‚Äù in the bottom left of the sheet ‚ó¶ 3. Attach (or make from the folder) the resulting zip file to the bug (will be named something like previews-diagnostics-0123456789.zip) ‚Ä¢ It‚Äôs particularly helpful if you can reproduce the issue with the previews logging profile installed. Instructions and profiles are available here: https://developer.apple.com/bug-reporting/profiles-and-logs/?name=swift. After installing the profile and reproducing the issue, then generate and attach the previews diagnostics. ‚Ä¢ A sample project is really helpful to help us narrow down any unique configuration options. ‚Ä¢ A screen recording helps illustrate the exact steps you used to reproduce the bug.

developer.apple.com
Profiles and Logs - Bug Reporting - Apple Developer
Get details on providing logs, reproducible test cases, and other information that will help us investigate and diagnose your reported issues.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/bug-reporting/profiles-and-logs/?name=swift
‚úÖ Karim-Pierre
‚ù§Ô∏è Adrian
Karim-Pierre
2022-06-09 23:34:33

*Thread Reply:* For issues with Preview on an iOS Simulator, which profile should we use? The macOS one?

Chris J (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:55:55

*Thread Reply:* yes, installing the profile to the macOS machine should suffice

‚úÖ Karim-Pierre

Our team loves to look at all of the feedback that gets sent our way. We‚Äôre excited to continue helping you build awesome apps!

This is particularly helpful with rows of a <code>List</code> as the <code>List</code> will also show those views with the correct list styling and metrics.</p> <p>We‚Äôd love feedback if you have a unique case that you don‚Äôt think is covered by the current solutions!</p>
